=100  \\$aSalzmann, Christian Gotthilf$d1744-1811$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q215060$94812
=245  \\$aUitvoerig verhaal hoe Ernst Haverveld van een' boer een vrijheer is geworden

=500  \\$aNovel for children
=500  \\$aChristian Gotthilf Salzmann was a German Protestant pastor and educator. In 1784, the Enlightenment philosopher founded the Philanthropin Schnepfenthal, a philanthropic educational institution near Gotha. 
=500  \\$aWillem Anthony Ockerse (Vianen, 16 April 1760 - The Hague, 19 January 1826) was a Dutch Reformed minister, broker, author, politician and leading patriot. Ockerse was the main author of the Staatsregeling van het Bataafsche Volk (State Regulation of the Batavian People) of March 1798 (the first Dutch constitution).

=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aGayot de Pitaval, François$d1673-1743$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q611445$94822
=245  \\$aCauses célèbres et intéressantes, $bavec les jugemens qui les ont décidées $n3, 5, 14/22
=260  \\$aThe Hague$bNeaulme$c1735-42
=300  \\$a3 vols. ([x]-336 + [iv]-400-[4] + xvi-430 pages)$bTitle pages in red & black ink
=500  \\$aCorrect year? The Neaulme edition began in 1747? Gayot de Pitaval (1673-1743) was a French lawyer who recorded numerous pithy scandals, such as de Affaire des Poisons
=500  \\$aA cause célèbre is an issue or incident arousing widespread controversy, outside campaigning, and heated public debate. The term continues in the media in all senses. It is sometimes used positively for celebrated legal cases for their precedent value and more often negatively for infamous ones, whether for scale, outrage, scandal, or conspiracy theories. The term is a French phrase in common usage in English. In French, cause means, here, a legal case, and célèbre means "famous". The phrase originated with the 37-volume Nouvelles Causes Célèbres, published in 1763, which was a collection of reports of well-known French court decisions from the 17th and 18th centuries.

=041  \\$afre$hgrc
=100  \\$aBoileau Despréaux, Nicolas$d1636-1711$4aut$4trl$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q188857$94839
=245  \\$aŒuvres diverses$bavec Le Traité du Sublime ou du merveilleux dans le discours$nvol. 2
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bSchelte$c1713
=300  \\$a344 pages$btitle page in red and black ink, 2 engraved frontispieces
=500  \\$asee also 06N04
=500  \\$aOn the Sublime is both a treatise on aesthetics and a work of literary criticism. It is written in an epistolary form and the final part, possibly dealing with public speaking, has been lost. The treatise is sometimes dedicated to Posthumius Terentianus, a cultured Roman and public figure, though little else is known of him. On the Sublime is a compendium of literary exemplars, with about fifty authors spanning 1,000 years mentioned or quoted. Along with the expected examples from Homer and other figures of Greek culture, Longinus refers to a passage from Genesis.

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aPook, Jan$d? -1714$4aut$94842
=245  \\$aDe hollebollige lachende docter, of Den bereysden Hans Zing-Zang;$bvermeerdert met den Verrezenen Pasquyn
=250  \\$a5th ed.
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bs.n.$c1728
=300  \\$a47 pages$c10 x 15,5 cm
=500  \\$aFirst part originally published in 1709:
https://www.let.leidenuniv.nl/Dutch/Ceneton/PookZingzang1709.html
=500  \\$aSecond part is a fragment from "Pasquin, from death returned: Or His Journey, Done in the Other World: Presented in a dialogue between him and Marforio. Translated from the Italian, increased and improved. Accompanied by several fine Copperplates.editied by Christiaan Karstensz, Amsterdam, 1677.
The dialogue on death is held between two of the most famous statues of Roman antiquity: Pasquino, whose name always designated the satire, and Marforio, the best known statue, who was represented with the image of Neptune. There seems to exsist an English translation of this work entitled "Pasquin risen from the dead, or his own relation of a late voyage he made to the other world. London, 1674" . 
=500  \\$a"Kamer-spel, aen geen byzondere rym-maat gebonden", containing songs (60 folksongs)
=500  \\$aPook was a folk poet from the first half of the 18th century, who, in the spirit of Jan van Gijsen (1668-1722), rhymed the events of the day and took a very active part in the theatrical disputes of his time.

=008  211123s1648\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\p\lat\d
=041  \\$alat
=245  \\$aSatyræ
=260  \\$aLeiden$bHack$c1648
=300  \\$a[xvi]-644-[42] pages$bbound in white vellum, title page engraving
=500  \\$aSee also 03F16 and 05B03 for different Dutch editions
=500  \\$aJuvenal's Satires is a series of 16 satirical poems, divided between 5 books. The poems meditate on life in Rome under the Emperor Domitian, and his successors. The Satires are especially well known for their uniquely caustic style, which is often contrasted with the urbane and witty style of Juvenal’s predecessor, Horace.
=500  \\$aPersius strikes the highest note that Roman satire reached; in earnestness and moral purpose he rises far superior to the political rancour or good-natured persiflage of his predecessors and the rhetorical indignation of Juvenal. 
=500  \\$ainteresting title page engraving by Reinier van Persijn (1615-1668) : allegory of discord: Elevation on which a woman in two minds. In her hands is a burning heart, symbolising virtue, and a mask, representing vice. She is flanked by a personification of America and Avarice. In the background, two satyrs are holding the curtain open for a window. The personification of Truth is crowned by angels. Below the image, in a cartouche, is the title in Latin.

=245  \\$aBeschreibung der grossen Orgel der Marienkirche zu Wismar sowie der grossen Orgel des Dames und der St. Martinikirche zu Halberstadt

=300  \\$ax-232-[3] pages
=500  \\$aBénigne Dujardin (1689, Paris – 1771?) was an 18th-century French writer, historian and translator. He was received Master of Requests in 1722 but didn't carry this title in 1738, probably because he fell out of favor. He then devoted himself to literature under the pseudonym (de) Boispréaux and in particular to translation, in association with Gottfried Sellius.

Als mede een beschrijving van verscheyde eylanden, steeden, zee-havens, oudheeden van Egypten, Turkyen en het Heylige Land: ook de gewoontens, zeden en straf-oefeningen deser volkeren

=041  \\$aeng
=245  \\$aThe Behavior of the Clergy, as Well as Their Traditions, Destructive of Religion
=260  \\$aLondon$bDodd$bCook$bChrichley$bJolyffe$c1731
=300  \\$a[ii]-viii-60 pages
=590  \\$aOr, a succinct history of priestcraft, throughout all ages. Containing, a general introduction of the institution of all pretended revelations. Remarks on priestcraft amongst the Greeks: the strange superstition of that learned people, proved to be the ruin of Athens. Remarks on Roman priestcraft, their augurs, pontiffs, &c. An account of the Bramins, Bonzées, Talapoins, and other Eastern priests: with a curious history of the Pharisees and Sadduces among the Jews. Popish priestcraft unveil'd, particularly with regard to our own island. Concluding with the secret intrigues of the gown with all parties from the Reformation to the vicars Ap---cy. Dedicated to the Most Worthy Sect of free-thinkers. That it may please thee to illuminate all Bishops, Priests and Deacons, with true knowledge and understanding of thy word and that both by thir preachinge and living they may set it forth and shew it accordingly. Liturgy of the Ch. of England

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aTijsens, Gijsbert$4aut$95005
=245  \\$aApollo's Marsdrager, veylende alderhande scherpzinnige en vermakelyke snel, punt, schimp en mengeldichten$nvols. 1 & 3
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bBosch$c1728
=300  \\$a2 vols. ([xv]-164-[12] pages+[xv]-172-[3] pages)
=500  \\$aThe publishers Valerius Maximus and Junius Juvenalis in the 1st volume are false/made up. The 1st volume is a reprint (date unknown) from the original in 1715, containing poetry from diverse authors. The third volume is added by printer Hendrik Bosch - a decision probably caused by the success of the first two volumes - and was mainly written by Gysbert Tysens (1693-1732) (more information: https://www.dbnl.org/tekst/zijd002gysb01_01/zijd002gysb01_01_0001.php)
=500  \\$aThe edition of the 1st volume is probably also printed by H. Bosch; in the back matter is a section called 'catalogus van boeken by Gerrit Bouman', a printer who was working together with Bosch. 
=500  \\$aValerius Maximus (fl. 14-37) was the author of the historical anecdotes 'Factorum ac dictorum memorabilium libri IX', written during the reign of Tiberius
=534  \\$aOriginal version (vol.1) published in 1715$ohttps://books.google.be/books?id=VI_Bkn9B-Q0C&dq=Apollo's%20Marsdrager%2C%20veylende%20alderhande%20scherpzinnige%20en%20vermakelyke%20snel%2C%20punt%2C%20schimp%20en%20mengeldichten&hl=nl&pg=PP9#v=onepage&q&f=false
=590  \\$avol. 1: En daar onder de Wetten van het Verkeerspel, de Lof van de Rhynsche wyn, een t'Samenspraak over de tabak &c. Met aardige Printjes verçiert. De Zeven- en negentigste druk. Vermeerdert met 37 Gedigten
Vol. 3: Met aardige Printjes verciert

=501  \\$aBound in with 'Res judicata', ‘Klare, ende krachtige bewijs-redenen…’, ‘Waerschouwinge…’, ‘Oordeel…’, ‘Nodige waerschouwinge tegen het oordeel…’, . =590  \\$aVraegs-gewijse voorgestelt van Seecker achtbaer ende seer geleert Man. Met een korte ende oprechte antwoort op deselve in 't Latijn beschreven... Daer achter by gevoeght zijn klare, en krachtige bewijs-redenen dat de Houder van de Leen-banck to Leyden, en oock alle andere Banck-houders, Leenende volgens ordonnantie haer van de Christelijcke Overigheyt voor-geschreven, niet en konnen, of behooren van het H. Avondtmael des Heeren geweert te werden.

=100  \\$aGrotius, Hugo$d1583-1645$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q154959$94890
=245  \\$aDe veritate religionis christianæ
=260  \\$aOxford$bSheldonian Theatre$c1675
=300  \\$a[x]-162 pages
=500  \\$aHugo/Huig de Groot (1583-1645) was a Dutch humanist
=500  \\$aGrotius composed a poem titled "Bewijs van den waren godsdienst" in a prison cell in 1620 after having been arrested by Prince Mauris. This didactic poem, whose title translates as "Proof of the True Religion," was first published in 1622 as a defense of Christianity against other religions and atheism. The Latin version of this poem, De Veritate Religionis Christianae ("On the Truth of the Christian Religion"), was later published in 1627.” The work contains six "books" with the first three touting the merits of Christianity, and the last three attacking paganism, Judaism, and Islam, respectively
=534  \\$aOriginal Dutch version printed in 1622$ohttps://books.google.be/books?id=ZpSFeAxNDE4C&dq=Bewijs%20van%20den%20waren%20godsdienst&pg=PP5#v=onepage&q&f=false

=041  \\$afre$hita
=100  \\$aVignola, Giacomo Barozzi da$4aut$95113
=245  \\$aReigles des cinq ordres d'architecture
=260  \\$aLyon$bBiesse
=300  \\$a97 pages$bill.
=500  \\$aPrinted by Laurent Biesse (1643-1713); specific date unknown
=500  \\$aThe 'Regola delli cinque ordini d'architettura' presented Vignola's practical system for constructing columns in the five classical orders (Tuscan, Doric, Ionic, Corinthian and Composite) utilising proportions which Vignola derived from his own measurements of classical Roman monuments. The clarity and ease of use of Vignola's treatise caused it to become in succeeding centuries the most published book in architectural history. (Source: Wikipedia)
=500  \\$aThe book consists mainly of illustrations alonsides descriptive notes
=534  \\$aOriginal Italian version printed in 1562, 1st french version printed in 1632$ohttps://books.google.be/books?id=CvD7xIOZNQMC&dq=Reigles%20des%20cinq%20ordres%20d'architecture&pg=PP5#v=onepage&q&f=false

=490  \\$aŒuvres de J. J. Rousseau$v1
=500  \\$aMarc-Michel Rey (1720-1780) was a Huguenot printer from Geneva who in 1744 moved to Amsterdam, where he succeeded to Jean-Frédéric Bernard. He was in personal touch with Rousseau. In 1769, Rey issued an 11-volume edition of the "Œuvres de J.-J. Rousseau de Genève. Nouvelle édition revue, corrigée & augmentée de plusieurs morceaux qui n'avoient point encore paru and three volumes of Œuvres diverses". He became the publisher of Voltaire, Rousseau, Diderot, Holbach, etc.

=952  \\$00$10$2ddc$40$6KTS_1_000000000000000_C1_67_03F14$70$8RAR$9451$aORPH$bORPH$cKTS1_C1$d2020-07-08$eKoopman$oKTS1 C1.67 03F14$p20138176$r2021-01-12 00:00:00$w2021-01-12$yBOO

=001  453
=008  220107s1684\\\\|||af|||\||||\00|\h\lat\d
=041  \\$alat
=245  \\$aSatyræ
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bWetsten$c1684
=300  \\$a[xliv]-525-[93]-112-[18] pages$bfrontispiece in red and black ink
=500  \\$asee also 01D20 and 05B03 for different Dutch editions
=500  \\$aJuvenal's Satires is a series of 16 satirical poems, divided between 5 books. The poems meditate on life in Rome under the Emperor Domitian, and his successors. The Satires are especially well known for their uniquely caustic style, which is often contrasted with the urbane and witty style of Juvenal’s predecessor, Horace.

=008  211027s1795\\\\|||fga||\||||\00|\0\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aVerschuere Reijnvaen, Joos$d1737-1808$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q11927169$95830
=245  \\$aMuzijkaal kunst-woordenboek, $bbehelzende de verklaaringen als mede het gebruik en de kracht der kunstwoorden, die in de muzijk voorkomen
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bBrave$c1795
=300  \\$axxii-[ii]-618 pages$b40 plates, musical examples, charts, illustrations
=500  \\$aJoos Verschuere Reynvaan was a Dutch composer , music writer, organist, carillonneur and doctor of law from the University of Harderwijk. On the cover of one of his works is the title of practicing lawyer (practiserend advocaat). His Musykaal konsworden boeck was the first Dutch work of its kind (Middelburg, 1789), which he did not finish, but later he wrote another work on the same subject, the first part of which it was printed in Amsterdam (1795), but it could not finish this work either. He also composed Cathechismus der Musik (Amsterdam, 1788), in which the author's name appears written Reynwaen. Of his compositions, only three piano sonatas were published.

=041  \\$ager
=100  \\$aSeidl, Wolfgang$d1491-1562$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q55127714$95233
=245  \\$aGeistlicher Layenspiegel$bdarinn man on groß vnd waitschwaiffigs nachlesen sehen vnd erkennen kan / ob die jetzgefürten Lehren auß dem Geist Gottes seyen / oder nit / Zu verhütung geferlicher Irrthumb / vnnd erhaltung des waren rechten Glaubens. Dem gemainen Mann diser Zeit vast nutz zulesen.
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aDillingen$bs.n.$c1559
=300  \\$a[xvi]-322 pages$billustrations
=500  \\$aExuberant Fraktur Font
=500  \\$aThe work commonly referred to as Laienspiegel is a book of law. 
=500  \\$aWolfgang Seidl was a Roman Catholic theologian, Benedictine monk and preacher during the Counter-Reformation. 
=500  \\$acontains ms. dedication
=500  \\$aincomplete: third part ends on page CLXI verso; last 18 pages are missing.

=008  211028s1790\\\\\\\g||||\||||\00|\0\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aRobbers, Jan$d1753-1830$4aut$95234
=245  \\$aTweetal proeven van verhandelingen, over de muzyk, als beeldende kunst, en de muzikale dichtkunde$bIn verband met de compositie van zangmuzyk
=260  \\$aRotterdam$bWijnhoven Hendriksen$c1790
=300  \\$a128 pages$b8 folded pages with musical examples
=500  \\$aProbably first edition
=500  \\$aJan Robbers was the organist of the Fransche Kerk en Groote Kerk in Rotterdam.
At the age of eighteen, Robbers moved to Rotterdam, where he became bell ringer of the Laurenskerk. In 1778 he was appointed organist of the same church - he held both positions until his death. He also acted as a judge of newly-built organs. His sonatas and sonatinas for harpsichord or piano are a wonderful example of the elegant, light music around 1800.

=100  \\$aFlorus, Lucius Annaeus$dc. 74-130$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q316483$95236
=245  \\$aEpitome rerum romanarum$bCum notis integris Cl. Salmasii et selectissimis Variorum accurante S.M.D.C. additus etiam L. Ampelius ex Bibliotheca L. Salmasii
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bElsevier$c1674
=300  \\$a[xvi]-588-[108]-46 pages$bengraved frontispiece, bound in white vellum
=500  \\$aOriginally 'Epitome de T. Livio Bellorum onium annorum DCC Libri duo' (c. 100)
=500  \\$aThis is the chief work of the Roman historian Lucius Annaeus Florus, who lived at the beginning 2nd century AD. It is an abridgement in four books of Roman history with special reference to the wars waged up to the age of Augustus. It may be considered to be an epitome of Livy, who he sometimes quotes verbatim. Florus also consulted works of Sallust and Caesar. The style is florid and poetic. Florus 'shows a certain literary gift, marred, however,by a strong tendency to rhetoric. His brevity often entails obscurity, though he sometimes produces a felicitous epigram. (.) As an historian he is often inaccurate in both chronology and geography, but the work as a whole achieves a limited success as a rapid sketch of Roman military history'. (OCD, 2nd ed. p. 442)
=500  \\$aClaude Saumaise (1588-1653) was a classical scholar
=500  \\$afrontispiece etched by C. V. Dalen (Cornelis van Dalen, 1602-1665)
=500  \\$a3 works in 1 volume: 1. Epitome rerum Romanarum, pages 1-459 -- 2. Epitome altera historiae Romanae; sive, Argumenta librorum T. Livii, etiam illorum qui interciderunt, eodem Floro, ut vulgo volunt, auctore, pages [461]-560, separate from the title page - Index, etc., pages 561-588 and [108] unnumbered pages -- 3. Lucius Ampelius ex bibliotheca Cl. Salmasii, 46 pages. with title page and new numbers but coeval index.

=008  211125s1798\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\0ddut\d
=041  \\$adut$hger
=100  \\$aHusen, Heinrich$4aut$95250
=245  \\$aGeheime papieren en bekentenis der Graavin van Lichtenau (vulgo Mientjen Encken)
=260  \\$aCharlottenburg$bs.n.$c1798
=300  \\$a34-36 pages$bengraved and colourored frontispiece 
=500  \\$aWilhelmine En(c)ke (also called Wilhelmina von Enk, Countess of Lichtenau (1753-1820) also called Countess of Dunkelheim, was the mistress of Frederik Willem II King of Prussia. During her lifetime, she was the subject of satire, and following fake memoirs, she published her own. After the king's death, his son immediately had Wilhelmine investigated for treason and embezzlement, among other things. Although the investigations came to nothing, Lichtenau was taken into fortress custody and banished to Glogau. In 1800, all her assets were confiscated and she received a pension instead. It was not until 1811 that Lichtenau was fully rehabilitated, after she had been partially compensated for her expropriated property in 1809 - at the intervention of Napoleon I - and allowed to return to Berlin.
=500  \\$adigitalisations german original:
https://digital.lb-oldenburg.de/vd18/content/titleinfo/623193
and
https://books.google.de/books?id=KbBVAAAAcAAJ&printsec=frontcover&hl=de&source=gbs_ge_summary_r#v=onepage&q&f=false
=500  \\$afrontispiece: engraved and colourored silhouette portrait of Wilhelmine
=504  \\$aWaltraud Maierhofer, "Wilhelmine Encke-Ritz-Lichtenau: Writing and Reading the Life of a Prussian Royal Mistress" 
University of Hawai'i Press , Volume 27, Number 3, Summer 2004, pp. 575-596
=534  \\$aGeheime Papiere der Gräfin von Lichtenau (vulgo Minchen Encken.)$cCharlottenburg : im Rietzischen Schlosse , 1798
=590  \\$aGetrokken uit de Schriften van den Man met de roode Muts

=500  \\$aElisabeth Maria Post was a Dutch poet and writer. She is considered one of the representatives of sentimentalism,  a literary movement in pre-Romanticism (18th century) which involved an exaggeration of romantic feelings, manifested in a strong hypersensitivity, and the search for things that could evoke pity and tears.
=500  \\$aConsiderations upon the death of a mother, inspired by the death in 1792 of Posts mother.

=245  \\$aComœdia vetus: bootsmans-praetje$bvermeerdert met Malle-Waegen, zijnde een Vervolg, en Verantwoording van de Comœdia Vetus
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bVisser$c1718
=300  \\$a[viii]-110-[18] pages$bengraved frontispiece and both title pages
=500  \\$aOriginally published in 1612
https://www.dbnl.org/tekst/meer040como01_01/colofon.php
https://books.google.be/books?id=JLRoAAAAcAAJ&lpg=PP14&ots=Lg5Xc1aBzZ&dq=Meerman%2C%20Willem&pg=PP11#v=onepage&q=Meerman,%20Willem&f=false
=500  \\$asatire in marine language, describing and commenting the conditions and theological quarrels at the time of the reformation and the counter-reformation. Original 1612 text by William Meerman , annotated and explained, with an additional alphabetical glossary of maritime terms by van Zonhoven.
=500  \\$abeautiful title-page of both parts
=500  \\$aWilliam Meerman, a sailor, son of a burgomaster of Delft, travelled in 1612 along the northern coasts of America, and left Comedia vetus of Bootsmans praetje, with wise notes by Van den Hoven, and a glossary of obscure Suranese words and also a satire of the theological quarrels between the Gomarists, by Franciscus Gomarus, and the Arminians, by Jacobus Arminius.

=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$aHollands Magazyn$n1a
=260  \\$aHaarlem$bBosch$c1750
=300  \\$a[xvi]-152 pages$bengraved title page, 4 inserted folded pages 
=500  \\$atitle-page with poem by Langendijk
=500  \\$aDutch magazine/paper "with geographical, historical, literary, medical, legal, theological, poetic, and oratorical observations, tests, questions, sketches, and treatises" that appeared with irregular frequency between 170 and 1761, and of which several editions were published together in bookform.
=500  \\$acontains "Proefondervindingen over de ademhaling", a letter about medical issues on breathing by Mr. Bremond.
=500  \\$abegins with an 'Interpretation of the Tytel-Prent', (explanation of the title page) in the form of a poem by Pieter Langendijk, followed by the title print on which a facade stone of a Dutch warehouse is revealed (Jan Caspar Philips inv. et fec.).
=500  \\$adedicated to George Clifford (1685-1760) , 'one of the first pillars of the country's renowned commerce; a famous mediator and an excellent promoter of the arts and sciences' Clifford was a Dutch merchant and banker. He is best known as the botanist and zoologist who employed Carl Linnaeus between 1735 and 1738. Clifford was an exponent of the growing public interest in science that developed in the first half of the eighteenth century.

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aLa Fargue, Jean Thomas$dc. 1700-1774$4aut$95282
=245  \\$aBeschryvinge van het recht en de gesteltenisse der Barrière
=260  \\$aThe Hague$bDe Cros$c1746
=300  \\$a[iv]-172 pages
=500  \\$aLa Fargue was a French poet, notary, and orangist pamphletist. Being a fleeing Huguenot he settled in the Netherlands and married Charlotte Constantia van Nieuwland (1703 -1785). 
=500  \\$aThe treatise of Barriere was declared in 1709 in The Hague and 1715 in Antwerp, whereby the Dutch Republic v. Germany and England was granted the right to erect a barrier in the Eastern Netherlands against France by laying siege to a number of towns (barrier towns). In 1781 the barrier towns were evacuated by the Republic on request of Emperor Joseph II. The only time that the barrier towns had to serve against France, during the War of the Austrian Succession, they turned out to be completely useless because the fortifications were neglected and the occupation was insufficient (1744).

=501  \\$aComœdia vetus: bootsmans-praetje

=100  \\$aSmetius, Johannes$4aut$95284
=245  \\$aDe sarda seu carneola crucem et pisciculos referente ad quartum lapidis jactus infra Neomagum

=500  \\$aAnthonie Heinsius (23 November 1641, Delft – 3 August 1720, The Hague) was a Dutch statesman who served as Grand Pensionary of Holland from 1689 to his death in 1720.  In practice, the grand pensionary of Holland was the political leader of the entire Dutch Republic when there was no stadtholder at the centre of power.

=041  \\$ager
=100  \\$aSorge, Georg Andreas$d1703-1778$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q88592$97274
=245  \\$aAusführliche und deutliche Anweisung zur Rational-Rechnung,$bund der damit verknüpften Ausmessung und Abtheilung des Monochords
=260  \\$aBad Lobenstein$bSorge$c1749
=300  \\$a[viii]-308-[4] pages
=500  \\$a Sorge's membership in Lorenz Christoph Mizler's Correspondierender Societät der musicalischen Wissenschaften, to which he was admitted in 1747 as the fifteenth member after Johann Sebastian Bach, led to a number of disputes. The first of these was a dispute over a new tonal system introduced by Georg Philipp Telemann.
The initial cause was a dispute over a new tonal system of dividing the octave into 55 microintervals introduced by Georg Philipp Telemann. Since Telemann had only formulated the general conditions of his system, the Society, which was very involved in mathematical questions, insisted on receiving the exact mathematical calculation from the author. Since Telemann was unwilling to do so and was obviously neither aware of nor interested in such calculations, Sorge presented these mathematical definitions of Telemann's system in his writings after a dispute with the Societät member Christoph Gottlieb Schröter.

=500  \\$aSorge's membership in Lorenz Christoph Mizler's Correspondierender Societät der musicalischen Wissenschaften, to which he was admitted in 1747 as the fifteenth member after Johann Sebastian Bach, led to a number of disputes. The first of these was a dispute over a new tonal system introduced by Georg Philipp Telemann.
The initial cause was a dispute over a new tonal system of dividing the octave into 55 microintervals introduced by Georg Philipp Telemann. Since Telemann had only formulated the general conditions of his system, the Society, which was very involved in mathematical questions, insisted on receiving the exact mathematical calculation from the author. Since Telemann was unwilling to do so and was obviously neither aware of nor interested in such calculations, Sorge presented these mathematical definitions of Telemann's system in his writings after a dispute with the Societät member Christoph Gottlieb Schröter.

=100  \\$aAiken, John$d1747-1822$4aut$95433
=245  \\$aEssays on Song-Writing:$bwith a collection of such English Songs as are the most eminent for poetical merit. 
=250  \\$a2nd Ed.
=260  \\$aLondon$bJohnson$c1774
=300  \\$axiv-280 pages
=500  \\$aEnglish writer and doctor John Aikin is known for his collaboration with his sister Anna Laetitia Barbauld 'Evenings at Home', a collection of short stories for children, as well as his own ten volume 'General Biography'. Aikin practised as a physician before turning purely to literary pursuits in 1798. His poems, or 'English songs' draw inspiration from ancient Latin and Greek verse. An 'Essay on Song-Writing' is prefixed to the verses.

=059  \\$av org/kbd bc
=100  \\$aRemmers, Johan Adam$4cmp$95454
=245  \\$aMuzyk tot de christelijke gezangen, ten gebruik der doopsgezinde gemeente. $b... Geschikt voor orgel, klavier, en andere instrumenten
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bUylenbroek$c1793
=300  \\$a[72] pages$bQuarto oblong
=500  \\$a68 chants for melody (no words) and figured bass. 
=500  \\$aJohan Adam Remmers was organist of the Amsterdam Mennonite Church 'near the Lamb' from 1777 to 1780, thereafter of the Waalse Church in Amsterdam (thus still in 1793, and after 1806). His organ accompaniments to the Mennonite hymns of 1793 suggest that he was then organist of another Mennonite church (perhaps 'De Zon,' because the hymns are those of this congregation). 
=500  \\$aList of subscribers, including some organists
=500  \\$aMusic engraved by T.D. Raadt, 
=590  \\$avergaderende bij het Lam en den Toren, te Amsterdam
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899

=008  211104s1704\\\\\\\gfa||\||||\00|\0\ger\d
=041  \\$ager
=059  \\$aorg
=100  \\$aSamber, Johann Baptist$d1654-1717$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q38263774$95455
=245  \\$aManuductio ad organum.$bDas ist: Gründlich- und sichere Handleitung, Durch die höchst-nothwendige Solmisation zu der Edlen Schlag-Kunst.
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aSalzburg$bMayr$c1704
=300  \\$a[xvi]-177-[6] pages$b42 Plates, musical examples, oblong
=500  \\$aThe personality and work of the Austrian cathedral organist from the archdiocese of Salzburg, music theorist and court musician Johann Baptist Samber, have so far been little researched. His writings offer information on performance practice, organ music or organ building, basso continuo, counterpoint, musical rhetoric and solmisation. 
=500  \\$aSamber, who describes himself as a pupil of Andreas Hofer and Georg Muffat, wrote three important works on composition: 
the "Manuductio ad organum" (1704), a "Hand-Leitung zum Orgl-Schlagen", 
its sequel, the "Continuatio ad manuductionem organicam" (1707)
and the "Elucidatio musicae choralis" (1710).
It is characteristic of the first two works that Samber's instrumental and compositional instruction is based almost exclusively on the basso continuo and the traditional voice leading rules. Significant are his careful and detailed descriptions and remarks on German fugue compositions of the late 17th century.
Samber's third work, the "Elucidatio musicae choralis", teaches the basics for the performance of Gregorian chant. This choral teaching is aimed primarily at the next generation of clerics and aspiring organists and "regentes chori".

=500  \\$a"Continuatio ad Maniductionem organicam" see 04C06a
=504  \\$afacsimile reprint  Olms, Hildesheim, 2009. ISBN 978-3-487-14267-8 
=561  \\$aEx Libris Alfred Cortot (Plate) and Sambure (information provided by TK)
=590  \\$aDenen Anfangenden zu sondern Nutz und Ergoetzung, einigen Lehrmeistern aber zu Anleitung und Behueff, die Jugent mit geringer Muehe in guter Ordnung nach Anweisung dess zu End-gesetzten Registers zu instruiren. Sambt einer kurtz-verfassten Information von denen Kirchen- oder Choral-Tonen, wie solche geschwind zu erkennen, und auff denen in Cornet-Ton gestimmen Orgl-Wercken abzuschlagen seynd. Alles mit vilen in Kupffer gestochenen Figuren und Exemplen gezieret, und mit sonderbahren Fleiss zusammen getragen, auch das erste Mahl in den Druck gegeben

=100  \\$aGugl, Matthäus$d1683-1721$4aut$95458
=245  \\$aFundamenta partituræ in compendio data.$bDas Ist: Kurzer Und Gründlicher Unterricht, Den General-baß, Oder Die Partitur Nach Den Regeln Recht Und Wohl Schlagen Zu Lernen 
=260  \\$aAugsburg$bWolf$c1777
=300  \\$a52 pages$bmusical examples
=500  \\$athe 'Fundamenta partiturae' was published between 1719-1805 in 6 unchanged editions.
=500  \\$aGugl was organist, composer and music theorist. He can be traced as a member of the court music in Salzburg at the latest in 1705. Probably a pupil of J. B. Samber, whose successor as cathedral organist in Salzburg he became in 1717. Teacher at the Kapellhaus. Belonged to the "Salzburg Circle of Theorists", which consisted of court and cathedral musicians.

=008  211108s1648\\\\\\\c||||\||||\00|\h\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aMarnix van St. Aldegonde, Philips van$d1538-1598$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q701605$95502
=245  \\$aDe Bijencorf der H. Roomsche Kercke
=260  \\$aUtrecht$bBilsteyn$c1648
=300  \\$a[xiv]-[468]-[12] pages
=500  \\$aPhilips van Marnix, lord of Sint-Aldegonde (1540-1598) was a writer, diplomat, intellectual and consultant to William of Oranje. He may have authored the Wilhelmus.
=500  \\$a'De Byencorf der H. Roomsche Kercke' was in its time one of the most famous written combats against the Roman Catholic Church. The author does this in the form of a defense: he pretends to give an explanation of a work of a French Catholic known at that time, who calls on the Calvinists to rejoin the Mother Church. Marnix pretends to offer a positive addition to that booklet, but under that mask the Calvinist is speaking. Holy indignation alternates with coarse mockery that the contemporary could enjoy, just as he also accepted the verbose nature of the booklet without any objection. Supporters and opponents have devoured this booklet, as the reprints and the many writings about it show.
=500  \\$aDescriptive ms. notes in the back
=534  \\$aOriginally published in 1569
=590  \\$aBy den Auteur Vergroot ende Vermeerdeert
=648  \0$a16th Century (1501-1600)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7017$920944

=041  \\$afre
=059  \\$av
=100  \\$aBérard, Jean-Antoine$d1710-1772$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q1684590$95483
=245  \\$aL'Art du chant
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aParis$bDessaint; Saillant; Prault; Lambert$c1755
=300  \\$a[xvi]-158-[6]-34 pages$bmusical examples
=500  \\$adedicated to Madame de Pompadour, the official chief mistress of King Louis XV from 1745 to 1751, who remained influential as court favourite until her death
=500  \\$aincludes an anatomical plate of the lungs
=500  \\$aAuthorship claimed by the Abbé Blanchet, who afterward published his "L'art, ou les principes philosophiques du chant" (Paris, 1756) as "2. édition, corrigée & augmentée." a designation that arises from the publication in 1755 of L’art du chant, dedié a Madame de Pompadour by Jean-Antoine Bérard, whom Blanchet accuses of incorporating his material. The two works certainly include many passages which are almost identical, notably the first and third chapters, ‘La voix considérée par rapport au chant’ and ‘La formation de la voix’. Blanchet in turn seems to have based much of his work upon the physician and anatomist Antoine Ferrein’s De la formation de la voix de l’homme (1741), although he refutes this imputation.
Joseph Blanchet was not a musician but a priest and, in his own words, ‘homme de lettres amateur’.

=500  \\$aconcludes with a 34-page appendix containing vocal airs by Rameau, Campra and others.
=501  \\$aTartini's 'Traité des agrémens de la musique' (1775)

=500  \\$aGottfried (Godfrey) Keller (b. c. 1650, probably in Germany; † November 1704 in London), keyboard player and composer, is the author of a posthumously published method for basso continuo: A Compleat Method for attaining to Play a Thorough Bass upon either Organ, Harpsichord, or Theorbo-lute..... (John Cullen, 1707) 
=500  \\$aWilliam Holder was an English clergyman and music theorist of the 17th century. His most notable work was this widely known 1694 publication "A Treatise on the Natural Grounds and Principles of Harmony".
=590  \\$awith Variety of Proper Lessons, Fuges, and Examples to Explain the said Rules. Also Directions for Tuning an Harpsichord or Spinnet. By the late Mr. Godfey Keller.

=041  \\$ager
=100  \\$aSorge, Georg Andreas$d1703-1778$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q88592$97274
=245  \\$aCompendium harmonicum,$boder Kurzer Begriff der Lehre von der Harmonie, vor diejenigen welche den Generalbaß und die Composition studiren, in der Ordnung welche die Natur des Klangs an die Hand giebt
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aBad Lobenstein$bSorge$c1760
=300  \\$a[xiv]-121-[3]-[24] pages$bmusic examples
=500  \\$aSorge was an organist, composer, and, most notably, theorist. His references to Johann Sebastian Bach show that they were friends, and he composed three fugues for organ on the name BACH (BWV Anh. 107, 108 and 110). He joined Lorenz Christoph Mizler's Corresponding Society of Musical Sciences in 1747, just a month after Bach himself.
=500  \\$aSorge's writings on thorough-bass and harmony are very competent, and his theoretical grasp of unequal temperaments excelled even that of J. G. Neidhardt (though still taking 1⁄12 comma as an indivisible unit of measure. He cited Bach as 'witness' that regular 1⁄6-comma meantone temperament was inadequate to 'modern' harmony, and he dismissed Johann Philipp Kirnberger's schemes of temperament as 'no good'.[Wikipedia] 
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aMethod$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2250960$921402
=650  \0$aHarmony$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q184421$92358

=008  211115s1731\\\\|||gfa||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aPrelleur, Peter$d1705-1741$4aut$95540
=245  \\$aThe Modern Musick-Master or, The Universal Musician …
=260  \\$aLondon$bPrelleur$c1731
=300  \\$a[xii]-48-[iv]-48-[iv]-48-[iii]-48-[iv]-48-[iv]-48-[i]-20-4 pages$b6 folded pages, musical noatation, 6 engraved frontispieces
=500  \\$aContains: "An Introduction to Singing"
=500  \\$a"Directions for Playing on the Flute"
=500  \\$a"The Newest Method for Learners on the German Flute"
=500  \\$a"Instructions upon the Hautboy"
=500  \\$a"The Art of Playing on the Violin"
=500  \\$a"The Harpsichord Illustrated and Improv'd"
=500  \\$a"A Brief History of Musick, and a Musical Dictionary"
=500  \\$aContains 8 beautiful frontispieces, engraved by I.Smith, appropriate to each part, most depicting people playing musical instruments.
=500  \\$awith 7 folding plates of instruction, fingering charts, and musical examples
=500  \\$amainly musical notation, less text
=500  \\$aPeter Prelleur was of French extraction and in early life a writing master. About 1728 he was elected organist of St. Alban, Wood Street, and shortly afterwards engaged to play the harpsichord at Goodman's Fields Theatre, which he continued to do until the suppression of the theatre under the Licensing Act in 1 737, composing also the dances and occasional music. In 1730 he published « The Modern Musick Master, or, the Universal Musician/ containing an introduction to singing, instructions for playing the flute, German flute, hautboy, violin, and harpsichord, with a brief History of Music, and a Musical Dictionary ». In 1735 he was elected the first organist of Christ Church, Spitalfields. After the closing of Goodman's Fields Theatre he was engaged at a newly opened place of entertainment in Leman Street close by, called the New Wells, for which he composed some songs, and an interlude entitled « Baucis and Philemon », containing a good overture and some pleasing songs and duets, the score of which he published. Fifteen hymn tunes by him were included in a collection of twenty-four published by one Moze, an organist, in 1758, under the title of « Divine Melody », in which he is spoken of as if then dead. 
=504  \\$aindex
=590  \\$aContaining I An Introduction to Singing ... II Directions for Playing on the Flute ... III The Newest Method for Learners on the German Flute ... IV Instructions upon the Hautboy ... V The Art of Playing on the Violin... VI The Harpsichord Illustrated and Improv'd ... A Large collection of Airs and Lessons ... With a brief history of Musick ... to which is added a musical dictionary.

=650  \0$aMusic theory$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q193544$92662

=245  \\$aVerhandeling over de muziek
=260  \\$aThe Hague$bKlis$c1786
=300  \\$a[viii]-379 pages$b4 folded pages engraved, musical examples
=500  \\$afirst published in 1772?
=500  \\$amain part concerning "how to bring the keyboard instruments to perfection, with a description of a newly invented harpsichord, on which all possible sounds are pure..."
=590  \\$aWaer in men tracht, de zelve tot meerder klaerheit te brengen, ...ten welken einde, Het rechte gebruik der nooten, sleutels, maet- en andere tekenen wordt opgegeven, ... als mede Hoe men de clavier-instrumenten tot volkoomenheit kan brengen, met eene beschryving van een nieuw uitgevonden klavesimbel, waer op alle moogelyke klanken zuiver zyn, en Eindelyk is achter deeze verhandeling gevoegt eene lyst van konstwoorden der muziek, geschikt volgens het A, B, C; benevens een blatwyzer, en 8 plaeten

=245  \\$aDe Spanjaarden in Peru of de Dood van Rolla; Aballino, de Groote Bandiet; Liefde en Vaderland
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bDóll$c1796
=300  \\$a184-211-54 pages$billustrations
=490  \\$aZedelijk schouwtoneel der menschelijke hartstochten en daaden of Toneelstukken van Vernuft en Smaak$v1/16
=500  \\$aEach play is preceded by an etching showing a specific scene from the play.
=534  \\$aKotzebue's "Die Spanier in Peru, oder Rolla's Tod" was originally published in 1796. The Dutch translation premiered that very year in Amsterdam; Zschokke dramatized his novel  "Abällino, der grosse Bandit" (1793) in 1795. Its Dutch translation premiered in Amsterdam in 1796; "Liebe und Vaterland" by Ludwig Benedict Franz von Bilderbeck was first published in 1789. It's also know as "Erste Liebe" (1801).$ohttps://books.google.be/books?id=zNNqNJxynikC&printsec=frontcover&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false

=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$a Cava van Conseugra, een offer der vrouwelyke wraak - De jonge Richelieu of De Fransche Lovelace - Volsan, of de menschenhater door tegenspoed'
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bDóll$c1797
=300  \\$a130-148-54 pages$billustrations
=490  \\$aZedelijk schouwtoneel der menschelijke hartstochten en daaden of Toneelstukken van Vernuft en Smaak $v3/16
=500  \\$a"Cava von Conseugra, ein Opfer der Weiber-Rache" by Joseph Herbst premiered in 1794
=500  \\$aDuval was a French dramatist, sailor, architect, actor & theatre manager. "La Jeunesse du Duc de Richelieu, ou le Lovelace Français", he wrote together with Monvel, and premiered in 1796.
=500  \\$aThe title-page of "Volsan" suggests it may be a translation by Villenhoven of a somewhat older (anonymous) french play.
However, the two extant versions of the play - both published in Amsterdam - also suggest the opposite scenario: The Dutch version having been published in 1797 and the French as "Volsan ou le Misanthrope par Infortune" in 1798, both by J. Dòll. Since no information could be found about the author beyond references to this one play, it could be argued that he (or she) may have been a bilingual Dutch or Belgian playwright, who wrote and published the play in both languages.
=500  \\$aEach play is preceded by an etching showing a specific scene from the play.

=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$aKlara van Synau- Komplimenten en wind - De schuldige echtgenoot
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bDóll$c1799
=300  \\$a184-163-64 pages$billustrations
=490  \\$aZedelijk schouwtoneel der menschelijke hartstochten en daaden of Toneelstukken van Vernuft en Smaak$v6/16
=500  \\$a"Klara (Clara) von Synau. Ein Trauerspiel in 5 Aufzügen" by Christen Henrik Nielsen was published in 1797.
=500  \\$a"Komplimenten und Wind, ein Lustspiel in vier Akten" by Christian Friedrich Bretzner was published in 1796.
=500  \\$aBretzner was one of the most popular German librettists and comedy poets at the end of the 18th century. He's famous for writing the libretto to a singspiel entitled "Belmont und Constanze, oder Die Entführung aus dem Serail", produced in Berlin and adapted in 1782 by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and Gottlieb Stephanie as" Die Entführung aus dem Serail". Bretzner's operetta had been composed by Johann André. Bretzner protested publicly in 1782 in the Leipziger Zeitung against the plagiarism by Mozart and his librettist Johann Gottlieb Stephanie the Younger, who reworked the text according to Mozart's ideas. One difference between the two works was that Bretzner made his end on a positive note, with Selim Bassa turning out to be Belmonte's father. Some of Bretzner's songs, such as Vivat Bacchus, became very well known through Mozart's interpretation. The fact that Bretzner published a German adaptation of Mozart's "Così fan tutte" in 1794, "Weibertreue oder die Mädchen sind von Flandern", is interpreted as a sign of reconciliation or even adoration of Mozart.

=500  \\$a"Le Mari Coupable: Comedie En Trois Actes, En Prose" by Villeneuve was published in Paris in 1794.
=500  \\$aSophie Villeneuve borrowed her husband's name (François Du Plessy, 1755-1828?)  and used several other names and pseudonyms to have her plays printed and performed.
=500  \\$aEach play is preceded by an etching showing a specific scene from the play.

=245  \\$aBlanka en Henriko - De Abt de l'Epée - De Broeders
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bDóll$c1800
=300  \\$a115-128-138 pages$billustrations
=490  \\$aZedelijk schouwtoneel der menschelijke hartstochten en daaden of Toneelstukken van Vernuft en Smaak $v7/16
=500  \\$a"Blanca und Enrico : Ein Trauerspiel in fünf Aufzügen" by David Friedrich Gensicke was published in 1795.
=500  \\$a"L'Abbé de l'Épée, comédie historique en 5 actes et en prose" van Jean Nicolas Bouilly was  premiered in 1799, Paris, Comédie-Française.
=500  \\$aThe dutch version seems to be translated by Samuel Iperusz. Wiselius, for a performance in the "Nederduitschen Schouwburg te Amsterdam" in 1800.
=500  \\$a"L'Abbé de l'Épée" features Charles-Michel de l'Épée (1712-1789), inventor of sign language and creator of what has now become the National Institute for Young Deaf People in France. A great figure and benefactor of humanity, the abbot was celebrated as such from the end of the 18th century and throughout the 19th century, with Bouilly's play playing a large part in this cult, which was maintained mainly by the Institute for the Deaf and Dumb.
=500  \\$aBouilly is best known for writing a libretto, supposedly based on a true story, about a woman who disguises herself as a man to rescue her husband from prison, which formed the basis of Beethoven's opera Fidelio as well as a number of other operas.
=500  \\$a"Die Brüder, Schauspiel in Fünf Aufzügen" by Friedrich Eberhard Rambach was published in 1798.
=500  \\$aEach play is preceded by an etching showing a specific scene from the play.

=500  \\$aLa Bruyère's "L'homme à sentimens, ou Le Tartuffe des mœurs, Comédie en 5 actes et en vers", was first performed at Théâtre Italien, Paris, 1789.  It was based on Sheridan's "The School for Scandal", a comedy of manners in 5 acts, first  performed in London at Drury Lane Theatre 1777.

=500  \\$aL'école des femmes is a theatrical comedy considered by some critics to be one of Molière's finest achievements. It was first staged at the Palais Royal theatre on 26 December 1662 for the brother of the King.

=008  210527s1689\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\d\fre\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aMolière$d1622-1673$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q687$95673
=245  \\$aLe Sicilien ou L'Amour peintre
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bLe Jeune$bWettstein$c1689
=300  \\$a36 pages$billustration$c7x13 cm
=500  \\$aOne of 10 reprints of Molière's works, collected in a box


=500  \\$aLe Sicilien ou l'Amour peintre is a one-act comedy-ballet, with music by Lully.
This play, a precursor of the style known as opéra-comique, combines song, dance and comedy. Jean Baptiste Lully is said to have produced here his "best musical score [... thanks to] a happy balance between alternating musical interludes, the spoken word, the sung word and the vocal ensembles ".
The first performance of this work was given on 5 January 1667 in Saint-Germain-en-Laye.
When the play was revived at La Comédie Française on 9 June 1679, Marc-Antoine Charpentier composed the music , and on 10 March 1780, the music was composed by Antoine Dauvergne.
Camille Saint-Saëns composed the incidental music for the re-creation on 30 May 1892 at the Théatre français in Paris.
=501  \\$aDom Garcie de Navarre, ou Le prince jaloux
George Dandin ou Le mari confondu
L'Escole des femmes
L'Escole des maris
La Comtesse d'Escarbagnas
La Princesse d'Élide ensemble les plaisirs de l'isle enchantée
Le Mariage forcé

Mélicerte. Comédie pastorale héroique

=100  \\$aMolière$d1622-1673$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q687$95673

=500  \\$aLes Amants magnifiques is a comedy-ballet with music by Lully, composed and performed during the carnival of February 1670, during the festivities called Divertissement royal. This was the last time that Louis XIV appeared on stage as a dancer.

=008  210607s1762\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\0b\\\\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aPlutarchus$d46-after 119$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q41523$95727
=245  \\$aLes Vies des hommes illustres$cvols. 1-14/14
=260  \\$aParis$bCompagnie des Libraires$c1762
=300  \\$a7 vols. (342+335+379+385+402+349+381 pages)
=500  \\$aOriginally 'Βίοι Παράλληλοι' (2nd c. AD)
=500  \\$aPlutarch's Lives of the Noble Greeks and Romans, commonly called Parallel Lives or Plutarch's Lives, is a series of 48 biographies of famous men, arranged in pairs to illuminate their common moral virtues or failings, probably written at the beginning of the second century AD.The surviving Parallel Lives (Greek: Βίοι Παράλληλοι, Bíoi Parállēloi) comprises 23 pairs of biographies, each pair consisting of one Greek and one Roman of similar destiny, such as Alexander the Great and Julius Caesar, or Demosthenes and Cicero. 
=500  \\$aAndré Dacier - a first-rate translator, keeper of the King's library and soon to be perpetual secretary of the Académie française - delivered his first six Lives in 1694. He dedicated his entire translation in 1721 to the future Louis XV. Dacier, who first translated for young people, corrected the pagan errors by earlier existing French translations of the Greek tex, and delivered a moralized Plutarch , which reigned in libraries throughout the 18th century.

=100  \\$aMiller, Edward Rothesay$d1843-1915$4trl$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q11290371$95774
=245  \\$aPrincess Splendor, the Wood-Cutter's Daughter.$bJapanese Fairy Tale
=250  \\$a2nd ed.
=260  \\$aTokyo$bHasegawa$c1895
=300  \\$a92 pages$bprinted on crêpe paper / Hosho paper, illustrations (coloured woodblock engravings)
=490  \\$aJapanese fairy tale series$vextra no.
=500  \\$aPrinted on double leaves of crêpe paper folded in Japanese style
=500  \\$aThe Japanese Fairy Tale Series (1885-1922) were illustrated books that introduced Western readers to traditional Japanese folk tales in a series of beautifully illustrated crêpe-paper children’s books put out by an enterprising Japanese publisher named Takejiro Hasegawa. 
=500  \\$a The beautiful coloured wood engravings are anonymous. One double leave illustration is loose, and has a different format.
=500  \\$aThe Tale of the Bamboo Cutter is a monogatari (fictional prose narrative) containing elements of Japanese folklore. Written by an unknown author in the late 9th or early 10th century during the Heian period, it is considered the oldest surviving work in the monogatari form.
=500  \\$aThe story of a tiny fairy found shut up in the stem of a bamboo by an old wood-cutter who lived all alone with his wife in a little cottage at the foot of a mountain. The tiny fairy grew up into a fair and noble woman of supernatural radiance who lived a sad life.

=500  \\$aOriginal Japanese Poems of the Manyoshu Collection, the majority dating from the first half of the 8th century. Complete edition, selected, translated from the Japanese by Karl Florenz with a preface and notes. With colored wood engravings of Hanko, Kason, Mishima Yunosuke (Shoso) and Arai Shujiro (Yoshimune).
=500  \\$aPrinted on double leaves of crêpe paper folded in Japanese style.
=500  \\$aEnglish translation by Lloyd of the German Edition of 1894 by Florenz, a pioneer of German Japanology. Lloyd was a minister of the Church of England, fellow and Dean of Peterhouse, Cambridge, academic, translator, and biographer. He also served as an Anglican missionary and academic in Japan from 1884 until his death in 1911.

=100  \\$aNepos, Cornelius$dc. 110 BC-c. 25 BC$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q109594$921561
=245  \\$aVitæ excellentium imperatorum
=260  \\$aLeiden$bHack$c1658
=300  \\$a[xxiv]-393-[15] pages
=500  \\$aCornelius Nepos is the earliest extant Latin biographer. His work 'On Famous Men' grouped and chronicled the lives of about 400 men, both Roman and non-Roman, who he recognized as significant and important men. The only surviving remains of 'On Famous Men' are "On Eminent Foreign Generals" and, from his section on Roman Historians, writings on the lives of Porcius Cato and Atticus.

=500  \\$aCornelis van Alkemade was a Dutch historian and a passionate collector of antiquities, both coins and old manuscripts. Through his many publications, Van Alkemade acquired great authority in his time as a connoisseur of antiquities.
=500  \\$aPieter van der Schelling was a Dutch historian, collector and researcher of antiquities, who, after his marriage in 1717 to Alida van Alkemade began working with his father-in-law Cornelis van Alkemade, also a collector of antiquities. After Cornelis van Alkemade's death in 1737, Pieter van der Schelling continued his work.

=041  \\$aspa
=100  \\$aIriarte, Tomás de$d1750-1791$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q135326$95814
=245  \\$aLa música.$bPoema
=250  \\$a2nd ed.
=260  \\$aMadrid$bImprenta Real$c1784
=300  \\$a[xx]-126-xl pages
=500  \\$aIriarte (1750-1791) was a neoclassical poet who translated French dramas for the royal theater of Madrid. 'La música', in which he deals with the elements of music, its expression, value, uses in church, the theater and in private life, and possibilities for composition on Spanish texts, forced his international breakthrough.
=534  \\$aOriginally published in 1782.

=650  \0$aMusic philosophy and aesthetics$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2092865$921165

=041  \\$agrc
=100  \\$aAnacreon$d582 BC-485 BC$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q213484$95821
=245  \\$aAnacreontis odaria, ad textus Barnesiani fidem emendata.$bAccedunt variæ lectiones
=250  \\$aEd. altera
=260  \\$aLondon$bHowlett$c1813
=300  \\$a130 pages$billustrations
=500  \\$aThis edition of Anacreon was originally published in 1802 for which William Bulmer furnished a Greek font; the title-plates and vignettes were by Lavinia Forster.
=500  \\$aAnacreon (582 BC-485 BC) was a Greek lyric poet, notable for his drinking songs and erotic poems.  Anacreon wrote all of his poetry in the ancient Ionic dialect. Like all early lyric poetry, it was composed to be sung or recited to the accompaniment of music, usually the lyre. Anacreon's poetry touched on universal themes of love, infatuation, disappointment, revelry, parties, festivals and the observations of everyday people and life.
=500  \\$aEdition based on the one of Joshua Barnes (1705) 
=500  \\$a3 poems are translated in english, pensil, manuscript

=001  1257
=008  211220s1663\\\\|||a||||\||||\00|\0\ita\d
=041  \\$aita
=100  \\$aGuarini, Battista$d1538-1612$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q542039$95920
=245  \\$aIl pastor fido
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bPluymer$c1663
=300  \\$a[ii]-157-[11] pages$bgilded edges
=500  \\$a Il pastor fido is a tragicomedy by Battista Guarini in five acts or 6862 verses. It was written between 1580 and 1584 and first published as a book in Venice in 1590. The first performance may have taken place in 1593 in Siena; the first historically verified performance in 1595 in Crema. Guarini continued to revise the play after the first publication, the last revision being for the 20th edition of 1602 (Venice). It appeared in over a hundred editions following its first publication.

=500  \\$aIn Italian literature, Il pastor fido, among others, marks the transition from Italian Renaissance to Baroque theatre.
=500  \\$aTogether with Bonarelli's 'Filli di Sciro' and Tasso's 'Aminta', Guarini's 'Il pastor fido' is considered one of the masterpieces of the genre of the pastoral drama

=500  \\$aOne of the most famous plays of the 17th century, it inspired numerous madrigal composers, including Giaches de Wert, Claudio Monteverdi, Sigismondo d'India, Alessandro Grandi, Tarquinio Merula, and Heinrich Schütz; Philippe de Monte named a volume after the play. The first operatic treatment was Handel's HWV 8 in 1712. 
=534  \\$aOriginally published in 1603
=590  \\$aCon le rime del molte illystre Sigr. Cavre. Battista Guarini

=001  1265
=008  211221s1735\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\p\fre\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aGresset, Jean-Baptiste$d1709-1777$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q942163$95926
=245  \\$aVer-Vert ou Les voyages du perroquet de Nevers. $bPoème héroique
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bs.n.$c1735
=300  \\$a[iv]-32 pages
=500  \\$aOriginally published in 1734
=500  \\$aheroic-comic poem in four songs about a parrot
=500  \\$aAlthough domestication has existed for a very long time, the attachment of humans to animals, a feeling that seems natural to us today, has not always existed. It is estimated that it was in the 18th century that a deep attachment to animals emerged among the elites. At that time, the figure of the animal became an important subject of study and a fashionable theme, as illustrated by the poem Vert-vert, written in 1734 by the Jesuit Jean-Baptiste-Louis Gresset. This story, whose eponymous hero is a parrot, is indicative of the interest in domestic animals in the 18th century.
=500  \\$aThe story is pleasant, and Vert-vert was a considerable success, as numerous 18th and 19th century editions prove. However, the poem did not please the sisters of the Visitation, who had Gresset sanctioned. Relegated to the college of La Flèche, he finally left the orders in 1735. He continued to write, however, and became an academician in 1748.
=501  \\$aLa Pupille / Règlement pour l'Opéra de Paris / Le Caresme In-promptu et Le lutrin vivant. 
=504  \\$ahttps://bibulyon.hypotheses.org/1539
=520  \\$athe Visitandines of Nevers take in a parrot they name Vert-Vert. They give him all their attention and teach him some pious songs. Proud of their parrot, they decided to send it to the Visitation in Nantes. But on the journey, Vert-vert learns the coarse language of the boatmen and, when he arrives at the convent in Nantes, he scandalizes the nuns who immediately send him away. Back in Nevers, Vert-vert is so pampered that he dies of indigestion.
=520  \\$aUnderneath its light-hearted appearance, Vert-vert reflects a reality, the possession of pets in convents, and certain preoccupations of the Enlightenment. Thus Gresset chose a parrot as the main character at a time when these birds were the object of a real craze in France. Sources of prestige for their masters, parrots also interest scholars because, through their ability to speak, they blur the line between man and animal. This new interest led to lively debates on the existence of suffering in animals: while some admitted it, others restricted it to physical pain. Others still consider it non-existent, such as the Cartesians, who believe that God can make an animal suffer, an innocent creature untouched by original sin, is to think that God is unjust.

Finally, while Jean-Baptiste-Louis Gresset tells this story with humour, others use it to criticise an excessive attachment to animals, an attachment that is all the more dangerous because it is likely to divert man from his duties towards his fellow human beings and towards God. This is the case of La Critique de Vairvert, an anonymous satirical play published in 1748.

=500  \\$aThe Odes (Latin: Carmina) are a collection in four books of Latin lyric poems by Horace. The Horatian ode format and style has been emulated since by other poets.  Books 1 to 3 were published in 23 BC. A fourth book, consisting of 15 poems, was published in 13 BC.

=100  \\$aJustinian I$d482-565$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q41866$95973
=245  \\$aInstitutiones
=250  \\$a4th ed.
=260  \\$aToulouse$bStéréotype d'Herhan$c1808
=300  \\$a[viii]-348 pages
=500  \\$aOriginally published in 533
=500  \\$aJustinian I 'the Great' was Eastern Roman (Byzantine) Emperor from 527 to 565. He is widely regarded as a saint by Orthodox Christians, and is also commemorated by some Lutheran churches on 14 November
=500  \\$aJustinian achieved lasting fame through his judicial reforms, particularly through the complete revision of all Roman law, something that had not previously been attempted. The total of Justinian's legislation is known today as the Corpus juris civilis. It consists of the Codex Justinianeus, the Digesta or Pandectae, the Institutiones, and the Novellae.

=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aWortley Montagu, Mary$d1689-1762$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q235121$96026
=245  \\$aLetters of the Right Honourable Lady M--y W--y M--e:$bWritten during her Travels in Europe, Asia, and Africa$n1-2/2
=260  \\$aLondon$bCadell$c1789
=300  \\$a2 vols. (xi-[ii]-220 + 272 pages)$bengraved frontispiece
=500  \\$aLady Mary Wortley Montagu (née Pierrepont, 1689-1762) was an English aristocrat, writer, and poet. She is chiefly remembered for her letters, particularly her Turkish Embassy Letters describing her travels to the Ottoman Empire, as wife to the British ambassador to Turkey, which Billie Melman described as "the very first example of a secular work by a woman about the Muslim Orient". Her writings address and challenge the hindering contemporary social attitudes towards women and their intellectual and social growth. She had  a very special life-story and was often portrayed, as evidenced by the many paintings there are of her.
=500  \\$afrontispiece portrait of the Author in vol.1
=500  \\$aEdition 1763 in 3 vols. Digitalisation vol.1: https://books.google.be/books?id=YkMVAAAAQAAJ
=504  \\$a Melman, Billie. Women's Orients: English Women and the Middle East, 1718–1918. University of Michigan Press. 1992. Print.
=590  \\$aTo persons of distinction, Men of Letters, &c. in different Parts of Europe. Which contain among others accounts of the policy and manners of the Turks; Drawn from sources that have been inaccessible to other travelers? An new editidion to which are added Poems by the same author.

=500  \\$aEx Libris Genreral Hospital Birminham: Birmingham's civic and choral tradition produced together the Birmingham Festival which originated in the 1750s and 1760s under the auspices of Saint Martin Church and the General Hospital. Handel's Oratorios provided the musical fulcrum until Mendelssohn displaced him in the 1830ies.

=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aHercules, an Oratorio in Score. Composed in the Year 1744 [HWV 60]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1787-97
=300  \\$a248 pages$bFrontispiece engraving of the composer
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 34-39
=500  \\$aLibrettist Broughton, a lover of music, knew Handel, and supplied words for some of his compositions, including a libretto based on Sophocles' Women of Trachis and the ninth book of Ovid's Metamophises for the drama Hercules, first performed at the Haymarket in 1745.Handel's biographer, Paul Henry Lang, praises Broughton's libretto for its "good theatrical sense" and the way in which it peels away any extraneous elements of the narrative to concentrate on the central drama of jealousy.

=041  \\$alat
=059  \\$aS 2A T B 2ob bsn 2tpt 2vn vla vc bc
=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aA Grand Te Deum for the Peace of Utrech. Composed in the Year 1713 [HWV 278]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1788
=300  \\$a48 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 15-16
=500  \\$aTo celebrate the Treaty of Utrecht, which established the Peace of Utrecht in 1713, ending the War of the Spanish Succession, Händel composed a Te Deum, HWV 278, and a Jubilate Deo (Psalm 100), HWV 279. The combination of the two texts in English follows earlier models. The official premiere of the work was on 13 July 1713 in a service in St Paul's Cathedral in London. 
=501  \\$aA Grand Jubilate [HWV 279]
=585  \\$aThis exemplar was exhibited in 2013 at 'In vredesnaam: De Vrede van Utrecht, Rastatt en Baden, 1713-1714' (Centraal Museum, Utrecht; Wehrgeschichtliches Museum, Rastatt; Historisches Museum, Baden), see de Bruin & Brinkman 2013

=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aAn Ode or Serenata for the Birth Day of Queen Ann Composed in the Year 1736$b['Eternal Source of Light Divine', HWV 74]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1789 [?]
=300  \\$a44 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 54
=500  \\$aAnne, Princess Royal and Princess of Orange (1709-1759)[ was the second child and eldest daughter of King George II of Great Britain and his consort Caroline of Ansbach. She was the wife of William IV, Prince of Orange, the first hereditary stadtholder of all seven provinces of the Northern Netherlands. She was taught music (including singing, harpsichord, and composition) by Georg Friedrich Händel. Händel did not like teaching, but said he would "make the only exception for Anne, flower of princesses". She remained a lifelong supporter, attending his operas and subscribing to his music.

=500  \\$aHandel sets a poem which the English poet John Dryden wrote in 1687. The main theme of the text is the Pythagorean theory of harmonia mundi, that music was a central force in the Earth's creation.

=245  \\$aJoshua, a Sacred Oratorio in Score. Composed in the Year 1747 $b[HWV 64]
=260  \\$aLondon$c1789$bArnold
=300  \\$a169-[1] pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 56-60
=500  \\$aJoshua is based on the Biblical story of Joshua as the leader of the ancient Israelites. The story follows the Israelites from their passage over the Jordan River into Caanan and through the Battle of Jericho. The work also includes a love story elaborated from a few hints in the Biblical narrative between Caleb's daughter Achsah and Othniel, a young soldier.

=500  \\$aTrydell was also ordained deacon and installed rector of Kilnamanagh

=041  \\$ager
=059  \\$akbd
=100  \\$aSchicht, Johann Gottfried$d1753-1823$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q289660$96041
=245  \\$aAllgemeines Choral-Buch für Kirchen, Schulen, Gesangvereine, Orgel- und Pianoforte- Spieler:$bVierstimmig gesetzt$nvols. 1-3
=260  \\$aLeipzig$bBreitkopf & Härtel$c1819
=300  \\$a10-547 pages$coblong
=500  \\$a3 vols. in 1
=500  \\$ams. note in front matter: "Mon très cher ami, F. Martini, dèja attaché au lit par sa maladie, m'a fait present de cette oeuvre la veille de noël 1842 Rr. (?)"
=500  \\$aJohann Gottfried Schicht (1753-1823) was a German composer and conductor. He was the conductor of the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra from 1785 to 1810, when he was succeeded by Johann Philipp Christian Schulz. Schicht continued to work in Leipzig, serving as Thomaskantor, director of the Thomanerchor with responsibility for music in the city's churches. He was in post from 1810 until 1823, when he died, aged 69, in Leipzig.
=500  \\$aHis most important work is this great choirbook from 1819. Besides that, he wrote masses, motets, cantatas, a setting of the 100th Psalm, four Te deums, one piano concerto, sonatas and capriccio. He is believed to have been the editor of the first edition of Bach's motets.

=100  \\$aRiesbeck, Johann Kaspar$d1754-1786$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q930749$96047
=245  \\$aBriefe eines reisenden Franzosen über Deutschland an seinen Bruder zu Paris
=250  \\$a2nd ed.
=260  \\$aZürich$c1784
=300  \\$a2 vols. (430+408 pages)
=500  \\$aIn the form of letters allegedly written by a Frenchman traveling in Germany, Riesbeck exposes for the first time the gap between the French Enlightenment and Germany's backwardness, on the eve of the French Revolution; he severely criticizes the social and religious mores of his country, as well as its political administration; but he also underlines its strengths, particularly in scientific, literary and philosophical matters, to show himself convinced that the German nation possesses the qualities necessary for its regeneration.

=008  210317r17771733\\\af|||\||||\00|\d\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aGay, John$d1685-1732$4lbt$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q321660$96050
=245  \\$aAchilles. $bAn Opera
=260  \\$aLondon$bBell$c1777
=300  \\$a60 pages
=500  \\$aThe opera is a burlesque parody of the story of Achilles on Skyros, based on legends of Achilles as related by Bion, Ovid, and Statius (notably the latter's Achilleid). Unsuccessful attempts were made at the time to interpret the work as a political satire (as was Gay's The Beggar's Opera) but no convincing case has been made for this. Unlike The Beggar's Opera and Gay's other ballad opera, Polly, Achilles uses not only tunes from popular music, but also employs melodies from concertante works of Arcangelo Corelli. Achilles proved popular; the opera ran for over a month after its premiere on 10 February 1733.
=500  \\$aplate next to frontispiece containing an illustration of 'Mr. Mattocks in the Character of Achilles'
=534  \\$aOriginally published in 1733
=590  \\$aAs written by John Gay. Distinguished also the variations of the theatre, as performed, in two acts, at the Theatre Royal in Covent Garden, Regulated from the Prompt-Book, by Permission of the Managers, by Mr. Wild, prompter
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aLibretto$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q131084$94031
=650  \0$aBallad opera$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q119272$923822
=650  \0$aSatire$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q128758$921636
=651  \0$aLondon (United Kingdom)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q84$9123
=700  \\$4adp$aWild$96051
=856  \\$uhttps://www.loc.gov/resource/musschatz.17515.0/?sp=3$3Library of Congress

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aFeith, Rhijnvis$d1753-1824$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q1375304$95084
=245  \\$aDicht- en prozaïsche werken$nvols. 1-14
=260  \\$aRotterdam$aZwolle$bImmerzeel$bDoijer$c1824
=300  \\$a14 vols. (23-312+247+267+295-[2]+271+183-54+218+187+208+160+248+xx-216+xx-216+xvi-242 pages)
=500  \\$aRhijnvis Feith (1753-1824) was a poet from Zwolle who studied law in Leiden together with Willem Bilderdijk, by whom he was influenced
=500  \\$aThe last three volumes, 'Oden en gedichten' were printed in Zwolle by H. As. Zoon Doijer
=500  \\$aidentical to the (incomplete) series H3-087 & H3-088

=041  \\$alat
=100  \\$aClaudianus, Claudius$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q205947$96055
=245  \\$aOpera quæ exstant
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bElsevier$c1665
=300  \\$a[xxvi]-917-[15] pages
=500  \\$aClaudius Claudianus, known in English as Claudian (c. 370 – c. 404 AD), was a Latin poet associated with the court of the Roman emperor Honorius at Mediolanum (Milan), and particularly with the general Stilicho. His work, written almost entirely in hexameters or elegiac couplets, falls into three main categories: poems for Honorius, poems for Stilicho, and mythological epic.

=008  220323r1740\\\\|||af|||\||||\00|\0\fre\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aBoze, Claude Gros de$d1680-1753$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2977512$96057
=245  \\$aHistoire de l'Academie royale des inscriptions et belles-lettres$nvols. 1-3
=260  \\$aParis$bGuerin$c1740
=300  \\$a3 vols. (xxiii-150-251-[4]+471-[3]+468-[9] pages)$bgilded edges
=500  \\$aClaude Gros de Boze (1680-1753) was a French scholar and numismatist. Studying in Lyon and Paris, and settling in the latter around 1700, he gained the support of Nicolas-Joseph Foucault and thus (in 1705) became a pensionary of the Académie des inscriptions et belles-lettres. In 1706 he was made the Académie des inscriptions' perpetual secretary and in 1715 he was elected to the Académie Française. In 1719 he was made curator or garde of the Cabinet des médailles et antiques, a post he held until his death. With his student and assistant Jean-Jacques Barthélemy he developed a method of classifying medals and in 1723 completed an "inventory of medals, engraved stones and other antique rarities in the Cabinet du roy". In 1727 he was elected a member of the Académie royale de peinture et de sculpture and on 6 April 1749 even became a Fellow of the British Royal Society.

=008  220328s1818\\\\|||af|||\||||\00|\0\fre\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aGalin, Pierre$d1786-1821$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2093455$96073
=245  \\$aExposition d'une nouvelle méthode pour l'enseignement de la musique
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aParis$bRey et Gravier$c1818
=300  \\$a[iv]-284 pages
=500  \\$aPierre Galin (1786–1822) was a French music educator, and developer of what became the Galin-Paris-Chevé system.
He never published an explanation of his teaching system, although 'Exposition d'une nouvelle méthode pour l'enseignement de la musique' (Explanation of a New Way of Teaching Music) (1818), addressed to the teacher, sets out many of his ideas. In addition to his new notation, he advocated the use of méloplaste ("song-shaper"), a staff with no clef but only a keynote indicated, from which he pointed tunes with a stick for the students to sing. For rhythm, he advocated a chronomerist, a table of note values all clearly related to a single unit, which makes clear the accentual patterns. 
=500  \\$ams. notes in ink throughout the book
=648  \0$a19th Century (1801-1900)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q6955$920935
=650  \0$aMethod$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2250960$921402

=500  \\$aSir Charle Boyle (1676-1731) published his edition of Phalaris at the request of the scholars of Christ Church, Oxford, as part of the controversy with Dr. Richard Bentley (1662 -1742), which led to Swift’s Battle of the Books. 
=500  \\$aBentley's dissertation upon the epistles, published in 1699, proved that the letters in question, supposedly written in the 6th century BCE by the Sicilian tyrant Phalaris, were actually a forgery produced by a Greek sophist in the 2nd century CE.

=008  220509s1672\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0ddut\d
=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aWitt, Johan de$d1625-1672$4col$924107
=245  \\$aDortse en Haagse Woonsdag en Saturdag,$bOf nader opening van de Bibliotheeq Van Mr. Jan de Witth
=260  \\$as.l.$bs.n.$c1672
=300  \\$a12 pages
=500  \\$a12 pages of dialogue in the form of a pamphlet, on the content of the library of Johan de Witt, referring to the auction-catalogue published shortly after de Witt's assasination in 1672.
=500  \\$aLast 2 pages are an index of 57 available pamplets, called 'blauwe Boekjes'. Pamphlets of this kind from the 16th-18th centuries in the Netherlands were called blauwboekjes (Blue papers) because of the cheap blue paper often used for the cover. These pamphlets had a limited size, and could be on a variety of subjects, often political or religious. They were intended to persuade (or taunt) opponents and recruit supporters. 
=500  \\$aJohan de Witt was born in Dordrecht (hence "Dortenaar" in the subtitle) and died in The Hague ("Hagenaar").
=505  \\$gJohan de Witt served as Grand Pensionary of Holland for nineteen years during the Dutch Golden Age and the First Stadholderless Period, making him the most influential statesman of the Republic of the Seven United Netherlands. A gifted mathematician, he is also regarded as one of the founding figures of actuarial science. Although he is commonly referred to by his full name today, his wife and many of his contemporaries simply called him Jan.
Tragically, Johan and his brother Cornelis were brutally murdered and mutilated by Orangist agitators—an event that remains one of the most infamous and shameful episodes in Dutch history.
=590  \\$aZijnde een samenspraak tusschen een Hagenaar en Dortenaar
=648  \0$a17th Century (1601-1700)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7016$920923
=650  \0$aHistory$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q309$921403

=651  \0$aThe Hague (Netherlands)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q36600$910
=651  \0$aDordrecht (Netherlands)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q26421$921875

=100  \\$aFeijoo, Benito Jerónimo$d1676-1764$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q379753$96088
=245  \\$aTheatro crítico universal,$bo Discursos varios en todo género de materias, para desengaño de errores comunes $pvol. 1
=250  \\$a8th ed.
=260  \\$aMadrid$bHierro, del$c1749
=300  \\$a[xxviii]-400-[15] pages$bbound in white vellum
=500  \\$aFeijoo was a Benedictine Monk, scholar, essayist and literary critic, who led the Age of Enlightenment in Spain. He was an energetic popularizer noted for encouraging scientific and empirical thought in an effort to debunk myths and superstitions.
=500  \\$aTeatro crítico universal (1726–1739) is a multi-volume collection of essays that cover a range of subjects, from natural history and the then known sciences, education, history, religion, literature, philology, music, philosophy and medicine, down to superstitions, wonders and salient points of contemporary journalistic interest.

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aBurman, Pieter sr.$d1668-1741$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q730541$924121
=245  \\$aRedenvoering voor de comedie
=260  \\$aUtrecht$bWater, vande$c1711
=300  \\$a[xx]-32 pages
=500  \\$aidentical to 16B22f
=500  \\$aplea for the comedy
=500  \\$aPieter Burman the Elder (Utrecht 1668 - Leiden 1741) a Dutch classical scholar, was appointed Extraordinary Professor of Eloquence and Poetry in Utrecht in 1696.  In 1715 he held the office of Professor of History, Eloquence and Greek Languages in Leiden. He was highly esteemed by the poets of his time but he had also made many enemies because of his sharp pen. For example, he never missed an opportunity to denounce the clergy. In 1711, he took up arms against the theater-hostile Utrecht clergy. His "Speech for the Comedy," which first appeared in Latin, resulted in 13 pamphlets.
=500  \\$aSee also 07C33

=300  \\$a112 pages
=500  \\$aidentical to 16B22i
=500  \\$aPieter Burman the Elder (Utrecht 1668 - Leiden 1741) a Dutch classical scholar, was appointed Extraordinary Professor of Eloquence and Poetry in Utrecht in 1696. In 1715 he held the office of Professor of History, Eloquence and Greek Languages in Leiden. He was highly esteemed by the poets of his time but he had also made many enemies because of his sharp pen. For example, he never missed an opportunity to denounce the clergy. In 1711, he took up arms against the theater-hostile Utrecht clergy. His "Speech for the Comedy," which first appeared in Latin, resulted in 13 pamphlets. 
=500  \\$aSee also 07C32
=590  \\$at' Zamengesteld by Zes Utrechtze Predikanten, Nicolaus van Wingen, Abraham Josua Brakonier, Cornelius Boott, Aegidius vande Putt, Simon STratenus, Anthonius Driessen. Waar in, nevens hare lasterlyke en onware beschuldigingen, aangewezen worden haar gevaarlyke gronden, ontrent de Regeringe, en bedieninge des Godsdienst.

=500  \\$aSatirical speech, in which the Leiden professor Burman summons the students not to tire themselves with Latin and Greek, "those studies, which falsely carry the name of civilizing, and which are so harmful to piety, good name, scholarship and the coffers".

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aCrane, Johan de$d1676-1746$4aut$96092
=245  \\$aAf-scheyd en bevesting reden over Hand. 20. vs. 26. 27. 28
=260  \\$aMiddelburg$bSchryver$c1728
=300  \\$a[vi]-112 pages
=500  \\$aJohan de Crane belonged to a not inconsiderable family, that flourished for a long time in Zeeland. He was born February 23rd 1676, and after good school and academy education, on March 13th 1696 became a minister, he was called to Nisse, and confirmed there April 7th 1697, from where he left for Oostkapelle in 1703. His health forced him to ask for an honorable resignation in 1727, which was granted. After that time he lived in Middelburg, but still frequently visited the pulpit, both there and in his last congregation; he even had the rare privilege of being able to confirm his six successors in Oostkapelle over a period of nineteen years. He died in Middelburg on the 31st of December 1746.
