=500  \\$aContains 'Blessed are all they that fear the Lord' (3-voice), 'Hear my pray'r o Lord' (4-voice), 'Hear my prayer o Lord' (8-voice), 'I am the Resurrection' (4-voice), 'I cryed unto the Lord with my voice' (4-voice), 'I will alway give thanks unto the Lord' (3-voice), 'I will sing unto the Lord' (2-voice), 'Lord what love have I unto thy Lan' (2-voice), 'O be joyfull in God' (solo), 'O give thanks unto the Lord' (voice and instruments), 'O Lord God of my salvation' (3-voice), 'O Lord God of my salvation' (3-voice), 'O Lord grant the King a long life' (4/6-voice), 'O Lord I will praise thee' (4-voice), 'O Lord rebuke me not' (6-voice), 'O Lord thou hast searched me out' (3-voice), 'O praise the Lord ye that fear him' (4-voice), 'Out of the deep have I call'd' (2-voice), 'Praise the Lord o my soul' (3-voice), 'Rejoyce in the Lord' (voices and instruments), 'Sing praises unto the Lord o ye Saints' (4-voice), 'Sing unto God Oye Kingdoms' (solo), 'Sing unto the Lord & praise his name' (3-voice), 'The earth is the Lords' (solo), 'The Heav'ns declare the Glory of God' (3-voice), 'The Lord is King' (solo), 'The Lord is my strength' (4-voice), 'This is the day which the Lord hath made' (4/8-voice), 'Thou o God art praised in Sion' (2-voice), 'We wait for thy loveing kindnes' (3-voice), 'We will rejoyce in thy salvation' (4-voice)
=500  \\$aContains a portrait of William Croft
=500  \\$aMs. note: "A Birth-Day Present from my good and beloved Daughter Miriam (Mrs. Henry Crane) received with the affection and additional prayers, by W. H. Havergal. Shareshill Jan 18. 1865"

Jane Miriam Crane (formerly Havergal) published records of her father's life. William Henry Havergal (1793 – 1870) was an Anglican clergyman, writer, composer and hymnwriter, and a publisher of sermons and pamphlets. He was also the father of the hymn-writer and poet Frances Ridley Havergal and the clergyman and organist Henry East Havergal (1820–1875).

=500  \\$aThe duets are part of a binding with nine sets of duets for violins which once belonged, according to the inscription on the binding to "M. de Gallatin, 1er Lieutenant aux Gardes Suisses". This is Gabriel-Gaspar de Gallatin (1758-1838), a Swiss nobleman who fought in America in 1780-1781 against the British army and who later served in the Swiss Guard of Louis XVI

=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aLondon$bJones$c1688$c1693

=500  \\$aTwo volumes in one.
=500  \\$atitle page of Book One contains in handwriting the names of Roger Laurence (first owner? author of the ms figuring?), and Charles Walter (later owner?)
=500  \\$aBack page of Book Two contains some handwritten remarks on certain tumes.
=500  \\$aInserted engraved frontispiece by Simon Gribelin (1661-1733), depicting 3 angels playing the lute, viol and harp, might be from another edition (?1703)
=500  \\$aBulk of collection is for one voice. Some Songs for mixed chorus, duets.
=500  \\$aContains a meticulous handwritten listing (detailed alphabetical index) by Robert Spencer (former owner of the book?) on all the composers and comparative table of later editions.
=500  \\$aFront-endpaper contains ms notes in pencil by Robert Spencer  (former owner of the book?):
"Book I 1688 1st ed tp (title page) in laid , pp 75-8 damaged/
Book II 1693 1st ed
ms beaming obliterates some notation
inserted frontispiece.
ms figuring added
original binding, rebacked
First Book first edition is very rare."

=100  \\$aRousseau, Jean-Jacques$d1712-1778$4cmp$4lbt$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q6527$95214
=245  \\$aLe Devin du village. Intermède
=260  \\$aParis$bs.n.$c1753
=300  \\$a[ii]-94 pages
=500  \\$aRousseau's Devin du Village - a pastoral opera, composed of melodies and instrumental music in the Italian style, announcing the comic opera - was first performed on 18 October 1752 before the royal court at Fontainebleau, and for the public, on 1 March 1753 at the Théâtre du Palais-Royal in Paris.
=500  \\$aScore incomplete. Until page 94. Rest is missing.
=500  \\$aThe 1753 edition is dedicated to Charles Pinot Duclos (1704 -1772), writer and historian, member of the Académie des inscriptions et belles-lettres, protégé of Madame de Pompadour.

=500  \\$aJ. S. Schröter, a German composer and pianist,  was active in London from 1772. A few years after his premature death, the married Joseph Haydn met Rebecca Schroeter, fell in love with the young widow and dedicated his Trios op. 73 to her.

=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aJoseph [and His Brethren], a Sacred Oratorio in Score, Composed in the Year 1746 $b[HWV 59]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1788
=300  \\$a214 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 107-111
=500  \\$aHandel completed "Joseph" in the summer of 1743.  It is composed to an English language libretto by the Reverend James Miller, based on Apostolo Zeno's Italian language libretto for Giuseppe, an oratorio by Antonio Caldara. The libretto is based on the Biblical story of Joseph found in Genesis chapters 38–45. It received its premiere performance on 2 March 1744 at the Covent Garden Theatre.

=500  \\$aSaul is a dramatic oratorio in three acts. Taken from the First Book of Samuel, the story of Saul focuses on the first king of Israel's relationship with his eventual successor, David. Saul was first performed at the King's Theatre in London on 16 January 1739.

=500  \\$aTheodora  is a dramatic oratorio in three acts. It concerns the Christian martyr Theodora and her Christian-converted Roman lover, Didymus. It had its first performance at Covent Garden Theatre on 16 March 1750.

=059  \\$a2S 3A 2T 3B SATB 2ob 2bsn 2tpt 2hrn timp 3vn vla 2vc org bc
=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aSemele, a Dramatick Performance in Score. The Words Altered from Congreve, the Musick Composed in the Year 1743 $b[HWV 58]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1788
=300  \\$a191 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 24-28
=500  \\$aSemele is a 'musical drama', originally presented "after the manner of an oratorio" in three parts. Based on a pre-existent opera libretto by William Congreve, written around 1705–6 and originally set to music in John Eccles's opera Semele. Handel's text was adapted by an unknown collaborator. The work is an opera in all but name but was first presented in concert form at Covent Garden theatre on 10 February 1744. The story comes from Ovid's Metamorphoses and concerns Semele, mother of Bacchus. 
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aOratorio$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q85477$91825
=650  \0$aOpera$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q1344$92468

=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aTe Deum Composed in the Year 1743 for the Victory at Dettingen $b[HWV 283]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1797
=300  \\$a104 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 17-19
=500  \\$aThe Te Deum for the Victory at the Battle of Dettingen is the fifth and last setting by Handel of the 4th-century Ambrosian hymn, Te Deum, or We Praise Thee, O God. He wrote it in 1743, only a month after the battle itself, during which Britain and its allies Hannover and Austria soundly routed the French.

=041  \\$afre
=245  \\$aAntiquités
=260  \\$aParis; Augsburg$bHertel$c1781
=300  \\$a[48 pages]
=500  \\$aArchitectural ornaments, design for mirrors, mantelpieces, pedestals, vases, cabinets etc.


=500  \\$aCollection of plates from various publications, many by publisher-engraver Johann Georg Hertel from Augsburg in the late 18th century.
=505  \\$aIII. Cahier Desseins des Trumeaux, (series E from “Desseins de la Mode neuve au Gout antique pour les Architects en general et specialement pour servir a diverse Artisans.”) by J.F. Hauer: 4 plates / mantelpieces sold "chez Poilly, Paris": 5 plates / Churchdecorations: I.G. Hertel (engr) & I.W. (inv): plate 1-4 / design wave cabinet by I.G. König (inv) & Ioh.G. Hertel (engr): plate 1,3,4 / C.A. Grossmann (inv)" Neueste Schreiner Arbeit" 1776: frontispiece, plate 1 & 4 / E.Eichel (inv) - I.G. Hertel (engr): plate 1-4 / F. =041  \\$ager
=059  \\$aS T B SATB 2fl 2bn 2ob 2vla bc
=100  \\$aGraun, Carl Heinrich$d1704-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q161208$96249
=245  \\$aDer Tod Jesu. Eine Cantate
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aLeipzig$bBreitkopf$c1760
=300  \\$a116 pages
=500  \\$aManuscript index
=500  \\$aDer Tod Jesu (The Death of Jesus) is an oratorio libretto by Karl Wilhelm Ramler. The poem is part of the Empfindsamkeit movement of the 1750s. 
=500  \\$aAfter its premiere in 1755, it was performed annually on Good Friday until about 1880, when it was replaced by Bach's Mathew-passion.
=500  \\$aUnlike Bach's Passions, Graun's setting does not imbue the tenor soloist with the role of narrator or Evangelist, nor is the bass cast as Vox Christi. The music is post-Baroque, an italianate galant style, and contains little counterpoint (notably in the duet, no. 17) or fugal movements (chorus no. 14 is a double fugue). Instead, it gives prominence to melody and voice. All arias are da capo arias with stylistic borrowings from opera arias. Grauner's recitative settings are highly expressive, culminating in the moving simplicity of the bass's recitative no. 23 on the death of Jesus, "Er ist nicht mehr!" (He is no more!). The last chorus starts quite powerfully, but then ebbs away into a mystical silence. 
=561  \\$aEx Libris Kirchenmusik Esslingen (Stamp)

=041  \\$aeng
=059  \\$aSS MEZ T B 4S2ATB fl  2ob 2 bn 2hn 2 trp timp 2vn vla vc bc
=100  \\$aHandel, George Frideric$d1685-1759$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7302$94765
=245  \\$aThe Triumph of Time and Truth, $ban Oratorio in Score Composed in the Year 1751 [HWV 71]
=260  \\$aLondon$bArnold$c1795
=300  \\$a199 pages
=490  \\$aThe Works of G. F. Händel, Ed. in Score$vplate nos. 165-169
=500  \\$aIn March 1757, possibly without much involvement from the blind and aging Handel, the original italian oratorio was further expanded and revised, and the libretto reworked into English. Although Jephtha (1751) is considered the composer’s true last oratorio, this third version of Il trionfo comes later. 
=500  \\$aThe compilation of the text is attributed to Thomas Morell, the librettist of most of the late Handel oratorios. In the translation, however, he was able to draw on the English translation of Il trionfo del Tempo e della Verità by George Oldmixon, published in 1737. The introduction of a new character, Deceit, can be traced back to him. 
=500  \\$aThe performance was conducted - as with other concerts of Handel's works in this phase - by his assistant John Christopher Smith. It is not known what role Smith otherwise played in this composition. He probably modified the score according to Handel's oral instructions.
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aOratorio$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q85477$91825
=651  \0$aUnited Kingdom$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q21$9273

=041  \\$afre$alat$adut
=100  \\$aHuygens, Constantijn$d1596-1687$4aut$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q560746$95174
=245  \\$aMusique et musiciens au XVIIe siècle :$bCorrespondance et œuvres musicales
=260  \\$aLeiden$bBrill$c1882
=300  \\$accxci-[7]-84-[81] pages
=500  \\$acited in Koopman 1985, p. 13
=500  \\$aThe collection Pathodia sacra et profana contains compositions by the scholar and composer Constantijn Huygens. It contains 39 compositions for voice and basso continuo: twenty psalms and nineteen "airs", twelve of which are on Italian poems and seven on French. The first word in the title, "pathodia", is described by the musicologist Rudolf Rasch as a 'Huygenian neologism', a contraction of 'pathos' (feeling, passion) and 'odè' (singing). This word seems to indicate a relationship with Joan Albert Bans' 'musica flexanima'.
=500  \\$aThe name of the composer is missing from the title page of the 'Pathodia sacra et profana'. Instead it reads the cryptic "occupati", usually translated as "of a busy man". With this Huygens indicates that he is not a professional musician. In his letters, he often refers to his compositions.
=501  \\$aHuygens' 'Pathodia sacra et profana' (1647); collotype printing by M.L. Verveer
=648  \0$a17th Century (1601-1700)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7016$920923

=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aFanshawe, Ann$d1625 - 1680$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q1916372$96300
=245  \\$aMemoirs of Lady Fanshawe,$bwife of the Right Hon. Sir Richard Fanshawe, Bart. Ambassador from Charles the Second to the Court of Madrid in 1661. Written by herself.
=260  \\$aLondon$bColburn$c1829
=300  \\$alxiii-395-[5] pages$bengraved frontispiece, leather spine elaborately embossed with gold
=500  \\$aAnn Fanshawe (boorn Harrison), was an English memoirist and cookery author. Her recipe for ice cream is thought to be the earliest recorded in Europe. 
=500  \\$aAfter the death of her husband Sir Richard Fanshawe (an English diplomat, poet and translator) Anne Fanshawe wrote her Memoir (1676), for use in the family, especially for her son. It offers a colorful account of their adventurous lives and also provides fascinating details about clothing and the varied customs they encountered during their travels. The Memoirs of Lady Fanshawe was not first published in full until 1829. A modern edition appeared in 1979
=500  \\$aRichard Fanshawe translated Guarini's 'Il Pastor Fido' into English, see 06F04
=500  \\$afrontispiece portrait of Lady Fanshawe, engraved by Meyer
=504  \\$aindex
=561  \\$aEx libris Henry Jenkinson (manuscript)

=500  \\$aThe Universal Magazine of Knowledge and Pleasure was a periodical published in London in the period 1747–1814 by John Hinton and W. Bent.
=500  \\$a2 vols. in one
=500  \\$afirst edition complete with 19 plates, one hand-coloured (including folding map of the Present Seat of War in North America and plates of the Open-Bellied Crocodile of the Ganges) bound with volume LXI printed 1777 complete with 20 plates (including Curious Experiments, and new species of Cuckow – the Honey Guide)
=500  \\$aThe chapters "The Life of Archangelo Corelli "  and The General History and peculiar Character of the Works of Archangelo Corelli'" (edition April 1777, p.169-172) are proceded by a portrait of A.Corelli (p.169) " ...a beautiful Engraving of his Head, from a Portrait by the late Mr. Henry Howard" (1697 ).

=590  \\$aContaining News, Letters, Debates, Poetry, Musick, Biography, History,Geography, Voyages,n Criticism, Translations, Philosophy, Mathematics, Husbandry, Gardening, Coockery, Chemistry, Mechanics, Trade, Navigation, Architecture and other Arts and Sciences which may render it Instructive and Entertaining to Gentry, Farmers and Tradesmen: To which occasionally will be added An Impartial Account of Books in several Languages, and of the State of Learning in Europe: Also Of the Stage, New Operas, Plays and Oratorios.

=500  \\$aGeorg Joseph Vogler, also known as Abbé Vogler (1749-1814), was a German composer, organist, teacher and theorist. In a long and colorful career extending over many more nations and decades than was usual at the time, Vogler established himself as a foremost experimenter in baroque and early classic music.

=500  \\$aThe Plantin-Moretus Museum is a printing museum in Antwerp, Belgium which focuses on the work of the 16th-century printers Christophe Plantin and Jan Moretus. It is located in their former residence and printing establishment, the Plantin Press, at the Vrijdagmarkt (Friday Market) in Antwerp, and has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2005.

=300  \\$a[xx]-374-[26]$bfolded page
=500  \\$aJohn Taylor (1703-1772) was a quack oculist associated with the surgical mistreatment of Bach (Leipzig, March 1750, leading to the composer's blindness and eventual death), Handel (Tunbridge Wells, August 1758, leading to the composer's death in April 1759) and others
=500  \\$asee H2-064 for an earlier French translation
=534  \\$aOriginally 'An Account of the Mechanism of the Eye' (1727)
=561  \\$aEx libris Hennemannsche Stiftung (stamp)
=590  \\$aJohann Taylors, Ritters, Doctors der Arzneykunst, Seiner Großbritannischen Majestät, und verschiedener anderen Durchlauchtigsten Fürsten hochbestallten Augenarztes wie auch Mitgliedes vieler Europäischen berühmten Academien der Wissenschaften u u.
Mechanismus oder Neue Abhandlung von der künstlichen Zusammensetzung des Menschliche Auges und den besonderen Nutzen desselben, sowohl vor sich, als in Absicht der anliegen Theile, Nebst Seiner Art, dessen Krankheiten zu heilen, Wie er solche bey einer mehr als zwanzigjährigen Erfahrung seiner durch Europa glücklich gethanen Augencuren bewährt befunden.
Mit den dazu gehörigen Kupfertafeln, Unter Königlich - Pohlnisch - und Chur-Sächsicher allergnädigsten Freyheit, und ausdrücklichen Bewilligung des Verfassers in Deutsche übersetzt.

=245  \\$aL'Éloge de la folie

=300  \\$a[viii]-xxiv-222 pages$btitle page in red and black ink, engraved frontispiece and title page, illustrations, 13 engraved plates
=500  \\$aIn Praise of Folly, also translated as The Praise of Folly (Latin: Stultitiae Laus or Moriae Encomium), is an essay written in Latin in 1509 by Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam and first printed in June 1511. It is a satirical attack on superstitions, other traditions of European society and on the Western Church.
=500  \\$abeautifully illustrated, indeed
engravings by Jacques-Nicolas Tardieu, Noël Le Mire, Jean-Baptiste Delafosse, Louis Legrand, Jean-Jacques Flipart, Jacques Aliamet

=500  \\$aContains 'Das Vorspiel , ein Satirische Episches Gedicht in fünf Büchern', a satirical-epic poem directed against Gottsched, originally published 1742, 
The volume also contains Rost's erotic-gallant poem "Der Brautnacht"(The Weddingnight)  (originally published as 'Die schöne Nacht' in 1754) one of those poems for which Rost was more notorious than famous and which "drove the fair blush of shame on virginal cheeks"
The two remaining poems, 'Der fröhliche Jüngling' and 'Die Nachtigall' , are not by Rost, but by J.Fr. Lamprecht and Chr. N. Neumann respectively.

=001  2323
=008  210701s1774\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\d\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aMerken, Lucretia Wilhelmina van$d1721-1789$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q3265974$95933
=245  \\$aJacob Simonszoon de Ryk. $bTreurspel
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bMeijer$c1774
=300  \\$a[iv]-87 pages
=500  \\$aVery succesful play about an episode in the Eighty Years' War (or Dutch War of Independence, 1568–1648), first staged at the Schouwburg of Amsterdam.
=500  \\$aThe play is set in Gent, in the Castle of the Counts (Gravensteen)
=500  \\$aIn 1774, the poet Lucretia Wilhelmina van Merken published a sensational play: Jacob Simonszoon de Ryk. This tragedy revolves around the heroic deeds of the sixteenth-century 'Watergeus' (Sea Beggar) De Rijk, a rebel during the Eighty Years' War who fled and issued with a privateer's certificate was entitled to fight as a privateer for the Republic against the Spanish. He ends up in Spanish captivity and becomes the focus of complex diplomatic negotiations. Thanks to his courage and perseverance, he manages to escape together with his four fellow combatants.
=500  \\$aJacob Simonszoon de Ryk was first performed at the reopening of the Amsterdamse Schouwburg in 1774. The crowds were so large that soldiers had to be called in to keep them under control. The heroic episode from the Eighty Years' War was so popular that it was performed many more times. It was a box-office success.
=500  \\$a Van Merken was in her day considered one of the best writers in the Netherlands. Contemporaries praised her poetic talent and called her 'the miracle of Europe'. She can rightly be called the female Vondel of the eighteenth century.
=500  \\$aMissing: pages 1-2,47-50

=008  210705s1611\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\i\mul\d
=041  \\$adut$alat
=245  \\$aBrief van Bernardus Forckenbeck aen Iacobum Omphalium; Brief van Bernardus Forckenbeck aen Henricum Welsingium; Brief van Jacobus Omphalius aen Aemilium Trebatium
=260  \\$aDeventer et al.$bs.n.$c1611
=300  \\$a32 pages
=500  \\$aBernardus Forckenberg, together with Henricus Welsing and Jacobus Omphalius, commissioned the anonymous book 'Officio hominis Christini', which defended the doctrines of Socinianism and advised the reader to join the Polish Socinians without delay. Socinianism is a Non-trinitarian Christian belief system named after the Italian theologians Lelio Sozzini (Latin: Laelius Socinus) and Fausto Sozzini (Latin: Faustus Socinus), which was developed among the Polish Brethren in the Polish Reformed Church during the 16th and 17th centuries. The Socinian booklet, defending Conrad Vorstius (1569-1622) a German-Dutch heterodox Remonstrant theologian, caused an uproar in Friesland. Even before the Frisian justice system could arrest the perpetrators, the three Vorstius-adepts made their way to Steinfurt.
=504  \\$ahttp://www.paulabels.nl/2009/03/kweekvijver/
=648  \0$a17th Century (1601-1700)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7016$920923

=651  \0$aNetherlands$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q55$9173

=700  \\$4aut$aOmphalius, Jacobus$96745

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aBosch Kemper, Jeronimo de$d1808-1876$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2271540$96746
=245  \\$aDirk Rafaelsz Camphuizen, de vrije evangelie-belijder in het tijdvak van het kerkelijk gezang
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bWitkamp$c1872
=300  \\$a32 pages
=500  \\$aDirk Rafelsz Camphuysen (1586-1627) was a Dutch painter, poet and theologian. Camphuysen left a translation of the Psalms, and a number of short pieces of poetry. He was also author of several theological works, among which is a Compendium Doctrinae Sociniorum. He was relatively successful as a minister, but he had embraced the doctrines of Arminianism, and like other Arminians or Remonstrants, he was banned from ministry and teaching and driven into exile (1619).The Remonstrants is a Protestant movement that had split from the Dutch Reformed Church in the early 17th century. The early Remonstrants supported Jacobus Arminius, and after his death, continued to maintain his original views called Arminianism against the proponents of Calvinism.

=590  \\$aDas ist: heylsame Betrachtungen für die zehentägige innerliche Versamblung, in welcher die Gottliebende geistliche beedes Geschlechts Ordens-Persohnen ihre Lebens-Jahr in der Bitterkeit ihrer Seelen widerholen, im Geist des Gemüths erneuren, und die Vollkommenheit zu erlangen, wie die Tauben seufftzend in die Fels-Löcher der Wunden JESU, und in die Steinritzen des Bergs Calvariä fliegen

=008  211217s1740\\\\|||f||||\||||\00|\0\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$aMaandelyksche berichten uit de andere waerelt, July-December 1740
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bRatelband$c1740
=300  \\$a642-107-[8] pages$b5 plates inserted
=500  \\$aThe 'Maandelyksche Berichten' are alternated with 'Staat nieuws' for every month
=500  \\$a"Het literaire genre van het dodengesprek (een fictief gesprek tussen twee of meer overledenen in het hiernamaals) is voor het eerst beoefend door de Grieks schrijvende Syriër Lucianus (120 – 180 na Chr.) Maar waar zijn Dodengesprekken een komisch en vooral satirisch karakter hadden, zijn de ‘Maandelyksche berichten’ hoofdzakelijk informatief van aard; ze geven stukken politieke geschiedenis en biografieën van de twee gesprekspartners. Ze zijn geschreven door de Duitser David Fassman en van 1718 tot 1739 in Leipzig uitgegeven. De Nederlandse vertalingen verschenen van 1721 tot en met 1754, en (samen met ander vertaald materiaal) van 1755 tot 1771, waarmee de ‘Maandelyksche berichten’ een van de langst verschenen Nederlandse tijdschriften van de achttiende eeuw zijn. Zie verder: Veenman, ‘Het dodengesprek in Nederland’, in: De Achttiende Eeuw 29 (1997)"
=561  \\$aEx libris Biblioth. Amstel (stamp)
=590  \\$aOf de spreekende dooden. Bestaande in redeneeringen, tusschen allerhande verstorvene Potentaten en Personagien van Rang; zo van den Deegen, Tabbaart, Letteren, als anders.

=041  \\$alat
=245  \\$aProprium sanctorum exemptæ cathedralis ecclasiæ et diocesis Labacensis
=260  \\$aSalzburg$bMayr$c1729
=300  \\$a122-[22] pages$bbinding with gold-printed ornaments, gilded edges
=500  \\$aRoman Breviary,  liturgical book used in the Roman Rite of the Catholic Church from 1568 to 1974. The Proprium Sanctorum contains special offices of saints 
=500  \\$aLiturgy from the Cathedral & diocese of Ljubljana, Slovenia
=500  \\$aSchrattenbach's coat of arms are engraved at p. 2
=500  \\$aSigmund Felix Graf von Schrattenbach (1679-1742) was Prince-Archbishop of Ljubljana from 1727 to 1742.
=500  \\$abeautiful binding with gold-printed ornaments and gilded edges
=590  \\$aAd normam Martyrologii, Missalis, ac Breviarii Romani accomodatius & emendatius editum Additis novissimis Festis, & Officiis

=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aBourdeille, Pierre de$d1540-1614$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q733270$95890
=245  \\$aMémoires de Messire Pierre de Bourdeille, Seigneur de Brantôme$c1-2/4
=260  \\$aLeiden$bSambix$c1699
=300  \\$a2 vols. ([iv]-308 + [iv]-304 pages)$b  $c8,5 x 14 cm
=500  \\$aThere also exists a fourth volume, see https://archive.org/details/mmoirescontenan00brangoog/page/n8
=500  \\$avol.3 = 09F22
=500  \\$aPierre de Bourdeille was a French historian, soldier and biographer.
=500  \\$aDe Bourdeille can hardly be regarded as a historian proper, and his Memoirs cannot be accepted as a very trustworthy source of information. But he writes in a quaint conversational way, pouring forth his thoughts, observations or facts without order or system, and with the greatest frankness.
His works give a picture of the general court-life of the time, with its unblushing and undisguised profligacy. There is not an homme illustre or a dame galante in all his gallery of portraits who has not engaged in sexual immorality; and yet the whole is narrated with the most complete unconsciousness that there is anything objectionable in their conduct.
[Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). "Pierre de Bourdeille, Seigneur and Abbé de Brantôme". Encyclopædia Britannica. 4 (11th ed.). Cambridge University Press.]
=561  \\$aex libris Paolo Gmo. Galetti 1784 (manuscript)
=590  \\$aLa Vies des Hommes illustres & grands Capitaines estrangers de son temps.

=650  \0$aBiography$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q36279$91927

=501  \\$aLampe's 'Geestelyke gezangen' (1724)
=590  \\$aTegens aansteekende siekten ter gunstige gemeener stichtinge, by dese gevaarlyke tyden, medegedeelt: eerst uytgegeven in den jare 1713 ende nu vermeerdert met een Gebedet, en een Predikatie over Ps. CXIX vers 175 gedaan na de verlossinge uyt een swaare krankheit, door Frederik Adolf Lampe, nu Hoog-Leeraar der H. Godgeleerdheid in Uytregt. Uyt het Hoogduytsch vertaalt door J. le Long.

=008  210907s1631\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\lat\d
=041  \\$alat
=100  \\$aSecundus, Johannes$d1511-1536$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q614229$96787
=245  \\$aOpera accurato recognita ex Museo P. Scriverii
=260  \\$aLeiden$bHeger, de$c1631
=300  \\$a[xxviii]-385 pages$b2 engravings, bound in white vellum
=500  \\$a Engraved title page with portrait medallion ("vatis amatoris iulia sculpta manu"); author's portrait on verso of tenth preliminary leaf. 
=500  \\$aJan Everaerts (Secundus) was a New Latin poet of Dutch nationality. He wrote elegies, epigrams, odes, epistles, epithalimia, itineraries, and other prose. His most famous work was Liber Basiorum (Book of Kisses) which is among the works in this volume (p.79-92) The compiler, Peter Schrijver (Scriverius) was was a Dutch antiquarian, philologist, writer and scholar on the history of Holland and Belgium.
=500  \\$aSecundus was a prolific writer, and in his short life he produced several books of elegies on his lovers Julia and Neaera, epigrams, odes, verse epistles and epithalamia, as well as some prose writings (epistles and itineraria).
His most famous work, though, was the Liber Basiorum (Book of Kisses, first complete edition 1541), a short collection consisting of nineteen poems in various metres, in which the poet explores the theme of the kiss in relation to his Spanish lover, Neaera.
=500  \\$aScriverius, was a profilic publisher of humanist literature. He collected manuscripts of Neolatine authors from his own time and from the time of early humanism. Based on these, he produced a number of editions, including the Latin poetry of Janus Secundus (first published in 1619).
=648  \0$a16th Century (1501-1600)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7017$920944

=008  210708s1767\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\dddut\d
=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aBuma, Johannes$d1694 -1756$4aut$96888
=245  \\$aBoere bruiloft, of Het huwelijk van Moddeworst, en Griet Beerdberg
=260  \\$aKnollendam$bs.n.$c1767
=500  \\$aHighly amusing and very detailed poetical description of a country-wedding, written in rather an indecent language; A farcical play is inserted. Extensive commentaries and some other prose accompany the poem.
=500  \\$aJohannes Buma (Leeuwarden 1694 - Leeuwarden 1756), son of a pharmacist, practised that profession himself for some time, but after his father's death he turned to painting and poetry. De Boere Bruiloft (The Merry Wedding), a satire on various well-known Frisian persons, has a long history: according to the biography that precedes the work, Buma started writing it between the ages of thirty and forty, after which it remained unfinished for sixteen years. At the insistence of friends, he finally completed it. It was only eleven years after his death, when all those involved had died, that the poem was dared to be published to spare the feelings of the dramatis personae still in life.
=500  \\$aBeautiful mezzotint portrait of Buma by R. Jelgerhuis after R. Keyert.
=500  \\$anote in pencil "de koperen platen zijn nooit verschenen", refers to the Koperen Platen (engraved illustrations) mentioned on the title page, but do not appear in the book.
=504  \\$aindex
=648  \0$a18th Century (1701-1800)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7015$920899
=650  \0$aPoetry$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q482$93026
=650  \0$aBiography$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q36279$91927
=650  \0$aSatire$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q128758$921636
=650  \0$aPlay (theater)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q25379$921414
=651  \0$aNetherlands$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q55$9173

=001  2550
=041  \\$ager
=100  \\$aGerbert, Martin$d1720-1793$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q66625$96622
=245  \\$aReisen durch Alemannien, Welschland und Frankreich, welche in den Jahren 1759. 1760. 1761 und 1762. angestellet worden
=260  \\$aUlm, Frankfurt, Leipzig$bWohler$c1767
=300  \\$a[xvi]-478-[9]-[18] pages$billustrations, 9 unnumbered pages inserted, some folded
=500  \\$aSoon after being appointed librarian of the monastery school in St. Blasien, Gerbert was sent on journeys from 1759 to 1762 for further education, which took him to Germany, Italy and France. He collected materials on the history of medieval liturgy and music and on the history of the monasteries and met many important personalities. Since Gerbert was initially entrusted with the administration of the monastery library, he began to study church history. The special object of his investigations became the history of church singing in the Middle Ages. Subsequently, he developed into an important music historian of modern times. His interest in music led to his acquaintance with Christoph Willibald Gluck, who became his friend. In 1760, during his travels, he collected copies of medieval treatises on music history and theory from monastery libraries. In Bologna he became friends with Padre Martini; both exchanged their rich experiences. The first result was the travel report 'Iter Alemannicum'.

=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aSmith, Robert$4aut$96924
=245  \\$aHarmonics$bor The Philosophy Of Musical Sounds
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aCambridge$bBentham$c1749
=300  \\$axvi-292-[13] pages$billustrations, 25 folded pages
=500  \\$afacsimile edition see 05A22
=500  \\$aSmith (1689 - 1768) trained as a mathematician and was Plumian Professor of Astronomy at Cambridge for forty-four years (1716 - 1760). Although his work on harmonics has a mathematical basis, he approaches the problems of tuning keyboard instruments as a musician would. 
=500  \\$a"Music was both Smith's pastime and his other main scientific interest. He was an accomplished performer on several instruments, particularly the violoncello, and possessed a 'correct ear'. In his Harmonics he advocated the mean-tone temperament or method of tuning keyboard instruments. In the same work he contributed to the mathematical theory of music with an extended discussion of equal harmonic intervals." (Geoffrey Canton in the new Oxford DNB)

=008  210713s1939\\\\\\\||k||\||||\00|\0\lat\d
=041  \\$alat
=059  \\$av
=245  \\$aLiber usualis missæ et officii pro domincis et festis cum cantu gregoriano
=260  \\$aParis; Tournai; Rome$bDesclée$c1939
=300  \\$axxix-[i]-1911-12-14-12-10 pages$bloose page (manuscript)
=500  \\$aThe Liber Usualis is a book of commonly used Gregorian chants in the Catholic tradition (11th century), compiled by the monks of the Abbey of Solesmes in France. The Liber was first edited in 1896 by Solesmes Abbot Dom André Mocquereau (1849–1930). Its use has decreased since the Second Vatican Ecumenical Council (opened by Pope John XXIII in 1962), in the constitution on the liturgy (Sacrosanctum Concilium), allowed the local language to be used in Church rites.

=100  \\$aWeiße, Christian Felix$d1726-1804$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q68815$95156

=260  \\$aReuttlingen$bFleischhauer$c1781
=300  \\$a2 vols. (306-[8] + 330-[6] pages)
=500  \\$aPublished earlier in 1777
=500  \\$aChristian Felix Weiße (1726–1804) a German writer and pedagogue, was among the leading representatives of the Enlightenment in Germany and is regarded as the founder of German children's literature. Four of his poems were set to music by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. His most lasting success were the librettos to Johann Adam Hiller's Singspiele.

=LDR  02790    a2200301   4500
=001  3047
=008  211208i17841786||||||||\||||\00|\p\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$aVaderlandsche liederen voor het Genootschap van Wapenhandel,$b ter spreuk voerende: Voor Vrijheid en Vaderland $n1-6/6
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aLeiden$bHeyligert$c1784-86
=300  \\$a6 vols. (40+38+44+40+40+40 pages)$b1 folded page musical example
=500  \\$aCollection of Dutch patriotic songs
=500  \\$aThe "Schutterijen" in the cities of the Dutch Republic, were traditionally militias, citizen's rifle companies organised as guilds. 
Civilian armament was one of the tenets of the Patriot movement of the 1780s, which resulted in either the existing civic militias being put at the service of the Patriot movement or, in addition to the traditional militias, new companies were established under names such as 'exercitiegenootschappen' or 'genootschap tot de wapenhandel' (arms trade). (Arms trade here means the handling of weapons).

=500  \\$aThe Patriot movement set a lot of songwriters' pens in motion, among others:
Vaderlandsche liederen voor het Genootschap van Wapenhandel ter spreuke gevoerd 'Voor Vrijheid en Vaderland', of which the first volume appeared in 1784. Five sequels appeared in the following years. They included works by Pieter Vreede (1750-1837) and by Pieter van Schelle (1749-1792), F. van Aken, J. 't Hooft Jz. and others. 
=500  \\$aIn the Patriot songs, a number of themes recur regularly: freedom fighters from the classical and recent past, freedom and patriotism, the marching bands, events from the short history of the Patriot movement, the leaders of the Patriot movement, Christian themes of justice, and - in an antagonistic sense - the stadholder and his allies.
=501  \\$aBataviesche liederen

=008  211208s1785\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\p\dut\d
=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$aBataviesche liederen voor de vrye Nederlanders, $bonder de spreuk Uit Vryheid en Vaderlandsliefde
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bWeege$c1785
=300  \\$a[91] pages
=500  \\$a Collection of Dutch patriotic songs

=500  \\$aThe "Schutterijen" in the cities of the Dutch Republic, were traditionally militias, citizen's rifle companies organised as guilds.
Civilian armament was one of the tenets of the Patriot movement of the 1780s, which resulted in either the existing civic militias being put at the service of the Patriot movement or, in addition to the traditional militias, new companies were established under names such as 'exercitiegenootschappen' or 'genootschap tot de wapenhandel' (arms trade). (Arms trade here means the handling of weapons).

=500  \\$aThe Patriot movement set a lot of songwriters' pens in motion, among others:
'Vaderlandsche liederen voor het Genootschap van Wapenhandel' - of which the first volume appeared in 1784 & five sequels appeared in the following years - and 'Batavian songs for the free Dutch' published in Amsterdam for the society 'Tot Nut der Schutterij' (To the benefit of the militia) in 1785.
=500  \\$aIn the Patriot songs, a number of themes recur regularly: 
freedom fighters from the classical and recent past, freedom and patriotism, the marching bands, events from the short history of the Patriot movement, the leaders of the Patriot movement, Christian themes of justice, and - in an antagonistic sense - the stadholder and his allies. 
=501  \\$aVaderlandsche liederen voor het Genootschap van Wapenhandel

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aGlazemaker, Jan Hendrik$d1620-1682$4trl$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2221565$97337
=245  \\$aToonneel der wereltsche veranderingen.$bdoor deftige, vermakelijke en ware geschiedenissen afgebeelt,$n1-2/2
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bHilten, van; Doornick$c1648; 1659
=300  \\$a2 vols. ([viii]-554 + [viii]-562 pages)$bbound in white vellum, illustrations, engraved title page
=500  \\$avol. 1 is published by van Hilten, vol. 2 by Doornik
=500  \\$aGlazemaker was a Dutch translator of almost 70 books, mostly from Latin and from French. Glazemaker probably lived and worked in Amsterdam, where most of his translations were published. He may have been the first person in history to make a living primarily by translating into Dutch. While much of his output was of the Latin classics, he was particularly noted for his translations of the writings of René Descartes from both French and Latin.
=500  \\$aA considerable number of the stories are translations of writings by the highly productive Bishop of Belley, Jean Pierre Camus, who in that first half of the century published some 960 short stories - in 21 collections - in addition to another 15 more or less substantial novels. Bishop at the age of 25, Camus felt called upon to counterbalance all the frivolities and absurdities he felt were appearing in this field with his stories and novels. The stories he published pretended to be true, since they were presented as examples of how things can go wrong when a person does not comply with Christian standards of a good life. To this end, they were usually provided with edifying introductions and conclusions. Glazemaker omitted these in his translations, which, had he known it, would undoubtedly have saddened Camus greatly. This left relatively short accounts of murders, rapes, adulteries and so on, which the reader was supposed to assume really happened, just as the reader of a newspaper is supposed to believe in the reality of mixed messages. But in between, Glazemaker included stories in his collection that apparently did not care about whether they really happened but about how striking the story is. 
=590  \\$adaar in, onder hoge en lage staten van menschen, zuivere liefden, schrikkelijke veinzingen, spitze vonden, bevallijke antwoorden, wrede moorden, verwoede wraken, rechtvaardige straffen en ontellijke sporeloze hertstochten spelen. Uit verscheide schrijvers

=100  \\$aPels, Andries$d1631-1681$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2787843$96280
=245  \\$aMengelzangen eerste en twéde deel
=250  \\$a2nd ed.
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bKunstgenootschap; van de Gaete; Bosch$c1717
=300  \\$a[iv]-256-[7] pages
=500  \\$athis is the first edition containing the second part
=500  \\$aAndries Pels was the co-founder, with Lodewijk Meyer, of the society Nil Volentibus Arduum (1669), which is mentioned in manuscript on the spine
=500  \\$aluxurious print with a beautiful, pastoral title-page, see preface: "Wy hebben u van tydt tót tydt médegedeeld alle de stukken door het Kunstgenootschap Nil Volentibus Arduum uitgegeeven, en geene moeite, vlyt, nóch kósten gespaard, om die Dichtwérken glans en luister by te zétten, zo door het versiere van ieder stuk met een zinlyke Tytelprent, ontworpen en gesneeden door kunstryke Meesters, als ook om het wérk zelve te doen verschynen, op zeer fraai papier met nétte druklétteren, indiervoegen dat niemand met récht ons iets béters zou kunnen afvórderen. Hier toe zyn wy niet alleen genoopt door liefde tót de kunst, maar ook door weêrzien in het zien der valsche naadrukken, t'elkens door baatzuchtige Ménschen den luiden in de handen gestooken, om ons goed oogmérk te dwarsboomen"

=041  \\$ager
=100  \\$aSlevogt, Gottlieb$dabout 1694-1732$4aut$97457
=245  \\$aGründliche Untersuchung von denen Rechten der Altäre, Tauf-Steine, Beicht-Stühle, Predigt-Stühle, Kirch-Stunde, Gottes-Künsten, Orgeln, Kirchen-Musik, Glocken, Thürmer und Gottes-Aecker$baus dem Canonischen und Protestantischen Kirchen-Recht erläutert
=260  \\$aJena$bRitter$c1732
=300  \\$a[xxxii]-517-[7] pages$bfrontispiece black & red, illustration, leather cover
=500  \\$aSlevogt was born at the end of the 17th century (details conspicuously unknown) in Jena, where he studied, received his doctorate in 1716 and devoted himself to the practice of law. He died in February 1732 as a ducal Altenburg court and government advocate and imperial comes palatinus, but left behind a heavy burden of debt, so that his family declined completely. Slevogt's writings belong mainly to Protestant canon law, which they treat sometimes historically-archaeologically, sometimes practically. His German work on the law of the altars combines both points of view with a mildly reasonable appreciation and toleration of all ceremonial activity.
=504  \\$aindex
=590  \\$anebst einer Einleitung von der innerlichen und äusserlichen Gestalt der ersten Kirchen. Mit einer Vorrede Herrn Just Henning Böhmers, weitberühmten ICti, königl. Preußischen Hochbetrauten Geheimbden Raths und Directoris der Königl. Friedrichs-Universität zu Halle, wie auch Prof. Publ. Ordinarii, von dem Schaden der Menschen-Satzungen bey dem Kirchen-Wesen

=100  \\$aSpieghel, Hendrik Laurensz$d1549-1612$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q262254$97458
=245  \\$aRederijck-kunst in rijm opt kortst vervat$bHier by ghevoeght de redenkaveling ende letter-kunsts grondvesten. Uytghegheven by de Kamer in Liefd' Bloeyende t'Amstelredam
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bBarentz$c1614
=300  \\$bfolded page$a32 pages
=500  \\$aOriginally published in 1587
=500  \\$acontains note (in pencil) at the back: "zelfstandig onderdeel van de Twe-Spraack van de Nederduitsche letterkunst, eerder uitgegeven in 1587, voor het eerst verzameld in 1614" (independent part of the Twe-Spraack of the Nederduitsche letterkunst, previously published in 1587, first collected in 1614)
=500  \\$aThe Twe-spraack is the first grammar of Dutch, published in 1584.
This" Rederijck-kunst" has page-numbers 257 to 283, which suggests the chapter was taken out of the Twe-spraack and bound in anew with an introduction addressed to the Chambers of Rhetoric.
=648  \0$a16th Century (1501-1600)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7017$920944

=008  210629s1815\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\0\fre\d
=041  \\$afre
=059  \\$av
=100  \\$aLa Feillée, François de$dc. 1700-1763$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q105946728$95432
=245  \\$aMéthode pour apprendre parfaitement les règles du plain-chant et de la psalmodie;$bAvec des Messes et autres Ouvrages en Plain-chant figuré et musical, à voix seule et en partie, à l'usage des Paroisses.
=260  \\$aAvignon$bGarrigan$c1815
=300  \\$aiv-492 pages
=500  \\$aLa Feillée, French botanist & abbot, was attached to the choir of Chartres Cathedral, in the mid 18th Century. By 1745, he was a composer and "theorist" at the Poitiers Cathedral. We owe him an abridged antiphonary, published in Paris by Hérissant in 1751, this manual of plainchant and some compositions.
=500  \\$aoriginally published in Poitiers, 1748
https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k98065737.texteImage

=500  \\$aJohannes Buxtorf was a celebrated Hebraist, member of a family of Orientalists; professor of Hebrew for thirty-nine years at Basel and was known by the title, "Master of the Rabbis". =590  \\$aop dicht-en sang-mate soo gerijmt, dat de eygene prophetische text-woorden daer in gehouden zijn, en met andere soorte van letteren, ordentlik daer uit gelesen en onderscheiden konnen worden. =500  \\$aSluyter was a Dutch Protestant preacher and poet. He was still read by the rural population in the 'Achterhoek' (a hamlet in the Dutch province of Gelderland) until well into the 19th century.

=590  \\$aAenwijsende, hoe men op een slechte en eensame plaets, buyten op 't lant vergenoegt mag leven... verçiert met eenige figuren, en vermeerdert met 43 bygevoegde gezangen, van den selven autheur, op dese stoffe en inhoud passende.

=100  \\$aLauremberg, Johann$cHans Willmsen L. Rost.$d1590-1658$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q97596$97694
=245  \\$aDe Veer olde beröhmede Schertz-Gedichte...$bin Nedder-Dütsch gerymet dörch Hans Willmsen L. Rost
=260  \\$aHamburg [?]$bs.n.$c1652
=300  \\$a135 pages
=500  \\$aJohann Lauremberg, also Johannes Lauremberg, occasionally incorrect: Johann Wilhelm Laurenberg (* 26 February 1590 in Rostock; † 28 February 1658 in Sorø, Denmark) was a mathematician and cartographer as well as a Low German poet and writer of the Baroque period. As a pseudonym he used the name "Hans Willmsen L. Rost." (= Johann, son of Wilhelm Lauremberg Rostochiensis).
=500  \\$afascinating volume in Low German or Low Saxon (Niedersächsisch / Nederduits)
=500  \\$aThe satirical Veer Schertzgedichte, in which Lauremberg mocks fashionable follies of his time, were translated into High German by Constantin Christian Dedekind in 1654,  and was newly published under the title "De nye poleerte Utiopische Bockes-Büdel. o. J." (c. 1700)
=590  \\$aI. Van der Minschen itzigen verdorvenen Wandel und Maneren
II. Van alamodischer Kleder-Dracht
III. Von vermegender Sprake unde Tituln
IV. Van Poesie unde Rym-Gedichten
Met eenen Anhang van etlichenin düssen Tyden nye ingeschleken Missbrücken.

=041  \\$apor$alat
=059  \\$aSATB
=100  \\$aSanta Maria Rosa, Bernardo de$4aut$97696
=245  \\$aAve Maria ponderada$bnovena da Immaculada Conceiçaõ da sempre Virgem Maria Mãy, e protectora dos Frades Menores
=260  \\$aCoimbra$bSimoens Ferreyra$c1747
=300  \\$a119 pages$bengraved frontispiece, musical examples
=500  \\$aA novena (from Latin: novem, "nine") is an ancient tradition of devotional praying in Christianity, consisting of private or public prayers repeated for nine successive days or weeks. The prayers are often derived from devotional prayer books, or consist of the recitation of the rosary (a "rosary novena"), or of short prayers through the day. Novena prayers are customarily printed in small booklets, and the novena is often dedicated to a specific angel, saint, Marian title of the Blessed Virgin Mary, or one of the persons of the Holy Trinity.
=500  \\$aAs the author Fr. Bernardo de Santa Maria Rosa was preacher and Master of Ceremonies of the Royal Convent of S. Francisco da Cidade do Porto, it could well be that this prayer/songbook was used at the Novenas for the Virgin in the liturgic rituals at the abbey mentioned. The feast day of the Virgin of the Immaculate Conception is 8 December.
=500  \\$aEngraved Frontispiece, iconography of the Virgin of the Immaculate Conception shows her standing, with arms outstretched or hands clasped in prayer.

=500  \\$aSaldenus was a dutch theologian and poet, avid supporter of Gisbertus Voetius (Dutch Calvinist theologian 1589-1676) He's known for his protest against theatre, dance, opulence, in other words against what was called in the circle of Voetius: the pride of the world.

=008  210719s1753\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\idfre\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aManassès de Pas de Feuquières, Antoine de$cMarquis$d1648 - 1711$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q587269$97698
=245  \\$aLettres et négociations du Marquis de Feuquières$bAmbassadeur extraordinaire du Roi en Allemagne, en 1633 & 1634$nvols. 1-2/3
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bNeaulme; Desaint & Saillant$c1753
=300  \\$a2 vols. ([vi]-ccxx-291+478 pages)
=500  \\$aVol. 3 is lacking
=500  \\$aAntoine de Pas, Marquis de Feuquières (1648 - 1711) was a French writer and soldier, who served in the wars of Louis XIV. His "Mémoires de M. le Marquis de Feuquiere, lieutenant general des armées du roi: contenans les maximes sur la guerre, & l'application des exemples aux maximes" ran to 42 editions between 1736 and 2014 and was translated into three languages. Completed just before his death in 1711, it was highly critical of Louis XIV and remained unpublished until 1736. Voltaire later used it as a source for his own work, "Siècle de Louis XIV". 
=500  \\$a The book begins with a long biographical presentation of the marquis written by the abbot Gabriel Pérau to whom  we owe this edition. 
=500  \\$aParticularly comprehensive, it includes a good understanding of the importance that France had in the Thirty Years' War and the particularly fundamental role of the Marquis de Feuquières in the formation of the alliance against the House of Austria.
=504  \\$ahttps://www.librairie-siblot.fr/images/2012/03/Lettres-et-n%c3%a9gociations-du-Marquis-de-Feuqui%c3%a8res-17532.pdf
=561  \\$aex libris Albert Verwey, (Plate) containing the motto "In de boeken mag men 't zoeken, in der minnen zal men 't vinnen"

=500  \\$aThe evangelical pastor Johann Spangenberg studied in Erfurt and later officiated in Hardegsen in the line of Martin Luther, while developing his talent as an organist and composer. He wrote his study on music in 1533 and his important collection of liturgical chant in 1545.

=008  210720s1653\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\fre\d
=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aJoly, Claude$d1607-1700$4aut$97709
=245  \\$aRecueil de maximes véritables et importantes pour l'institution du Roy
=260  \\$aParis$bElsevier$c1653
=300  \\$a[xxii]-584-[2] pages$bgilded pages
=500  \\$aThe most prominent rebellions in the mid-seventeenth century France were those of the nobles and the judges and known as the 'Fronde'.The leading theoretician of the parleamentary fronde was Claude Joly. His treatise 'Recueil de maximes' is a collection of constitutionalist maxims, remnants of a pre-absolutist age, and include trenchant attacks on two contributions of Cardinals Richelieu and Mazarin to political thought and practice in France. One was the new motion that the king is rightly the master - in effect the owner - of the persons and properties of all inhabitants of France. The other was the Machiavellian view that succesful public policy requires the systematic use of immoral means. The King's power, warned Joly, is limited and not automatically sanctionned by divine law. Frenchmen posess just title to their lives and properties, and are not the slaves of a despot or tyrant. The king's original divine power is mediated through the French people, Joly added, and the king cannot rightfully tax the French without the consent of the states-general. The fact that Joly was reviled by the king and his party as a rebel and a traitor, he declared, shows that the old constitutionhas been overcome by new views holding the king to have unlimited authority above all law. For Joly this view was 'pure usurpation'  bred in the 'monstrous cauldron' of Machiavel.
=561  \\$aEx Libris Lily Anderson (manuscript)
=590  \\$aContre la fausse & pernicieuse politique du Cardinal Mazarin, prétendu sur-intendant de l'éducation de Sa Majesté

=041  \\$afre
=100  \\$aRollin, Charles$d1661-1741$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2471187$95685
=245  \\$aLe Rollin de la jeunesse ou Morceaux choisis des histoires ancienne et romaine$bTome second. Histoire Romaine$nVol.2
=250  \\$a2nd ed.
=260  \\$aParis$bDelaunay$c1816
=300  \\$a492 pages$billustrations
=500  \\$aCharles Rollin (1661-1741) was a French historian and educator, very popular in his time. His literary work dates chiefly from the later years of his life, when he had been forbidden to teach. His once famous Ancient History (French: Histoire Ancienne, 12 vols., Paris, 1730–38) and the less generally read Roman History (Histoire Romaine, only five of nine volumes finished by the time of his death) were avowed compilations, uncritical and somewhat inaccurate. But they instructed and interested, generation after generation.

=590  \\$aWorinnen Nachricht gegeben wird, Was für eine Beschaffenheit es habe mit der Prærogativ, und dem daraus fliessenden Ceremoniel, Welches zwischen Käyser und Königl. Majestäten, Churfürsten, Cardinälen und freyen Republiquen, dero Gesandten und Abgesandten beobachtet wird ; Nebst beygefügtem Unterricht Was ein Legatus à Latere, Nuncius Apostolicus, Ambassadeur, Envoyé, Plenipotentarius ... so wohl seiner Würde als seinem Amte nach sey ... Auch was es wegen des Ceremoniels, auf Frieden-Schlüssen und bey Höfen, für Mißhelligkeiten gegeben ... ; Nebst vollständigen Register

=590  \\$aNel quale si vede chiaro non sol'il vero, facile, e breve modo d'imparar di cantare di canto figurato e fermo Ma vi si vedon' anco dichiarate con bellissim'ordine tutte le principali materie, che ivi si trattano, sciolte le maggiori difficoltà, che all'incipienti, proficienti, e perfetti in essa occorrono, e scoperti nuovi segreti nella medesima circa il cantare, comporre, e sonar di tasti, nascoti. Necessario d'haversi sempre da' predetti non sol' in camera per conservarlo Ma appresso di se per rimirarlo, intenderlo, e pratticarlo. Composto dal M. R. P. F. Silverio Picerli. =008  210722b\\\\\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\lat\d
=041  \\$alat
=100  \\$aVerdussen, Cornelius$4aut$97729
=245  \\$aCatalogus quorumdam librorum prostantium in officina viduæ Cornelii Verdussen & consortis Bibliopolæ Antverpiæ
=260  \\$aAntwerp$bs.n.$c17xx
=300  \\$a4 pages
=500  \\$aVerdussen was a dynasty of printers in Antwerp, starting with Hieronymus Verdussen I in the late sixteenth century, and ending around 1800. Many other printers in Antwerp were also related to the Verdussens through marriage. They specialized in religious works and works in Spanish,[1] but also published newspapers, almanachs, poetry, scientific works, .... By the end of the 17th century, they produced about 21% of the Spanish books printed in the Netherlands, and with 5 presses was second only to Moretus in Antwerp.
=500  \\$aCatalogue edited by the widow of Cornelius Verdussen & Partners.
=504  \\$ahttps://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verdussen_family

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aBoer, Francijntje de$d1784-1852$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q2299757$97737
=245  \\$aNieuwe dichtproeven$bvan Francijntje De Boer Dienstmaagd te Sneek
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bBeijerinck$c1821
=300  \\$a[xxii]-75-[1] pages$bclippings
=500  \\$aContains some loose clippings - papercraft and illustrations from printed sources - as well as a handwritten leaflet notificating the death of Francijntje de Boer
=500  \\$aFrancijntje de Boer was a Dutch maid and writer of particularly successful children's poems. Between 1815 and 1825, she published four volumes of poetry, three of which were for children. Her language is characterised by simplicity. Her poems revolve around domesticity, virtue and pure religiousness. Despite her modest social position, she had contact with other Dutch female poets, including Fenna Mastenbroek, Petronella Moens and Anna Barbara van Meerten-Schilperoort. During her lifetime, she enjoyed widespread fame. A total of eight editions of her 'Gedichtjes voor kinderen' appeared until the end of 1870, and a French translation by Auguste Clavareau in 1835. The various printings varied in design and illustration, and were widely distributed, serving in schools as prizes for pupils or as teaching material.

=041  \\$adut
=100  \\$aBredero, Gerbrand Adriaenszoon$d1585-1618$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q560740$94858
=245  \\$aOverghesette Lucelle$bGhespeelt op de Nederduytsche Academie
=260  \\$aAmsterdam$bPlassen, vander$c1621
=300  \\$a[72] pages
=500  \\$aOriginally published in 1616
=500  \\$aLucelle is a true Romeo & Juliet adaptation by Bredero. A play that moved Maria Tesselschade to tears at the premiere in 1615, a play that was immortalised many times by painters such as Jan Steen and Jan Miense Moleaer, a play that was reprinted more than any of Bredero's plays in the 17th and 18th centuries, a play with the recognisable topical emotion of unattainable love due to a difference in descent.
=500  \\$aFinal scene of the play painted by Molenaer:
https://www.pubhist.com/w7503

=500  \\$aBredero signs the play with 'overgeset en gerijmt' (translated and put in rhymes), pointing herewith at the fact that this tragicomedy was based on a foreing template, namely the ‘tragi-comedie en prose ’ Lucelle (1576) by the French writer Louis Le Jars
=500  \\$aDigitalisation of later print:
https://books.google.be/books?vid=GENT900000032285&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false
=501  \\$aTreurspel van Roddrick ende Alphonsus / Moortje / Spaanschen Brabander Ierolimo  / Griane / Stommen ridder / Epitaphium, ofte graf-dicht op 't overlyden vanden sinrijcken Poeets G. A. Brederode
=504  \\$aDiscussing the connection of the play with the French original:
https://www.dbnl.org/tekst/bred001luce01_01/bred001luce01_01_0002.php

=100  \\$aWerckmeister, Andreas$d1645-1706$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q61162$94936
=245  \\$aMusicalische Paradoxal-Discourse oder Ungemeine Vorstellungen wie die Musica einen hohen und göttlichen Ursprung habe
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aQuedlinburg$bCalvisi$c1707
=300  \\$a[iv[-120- [2] pages$bmusical examples
=500  \\$aOrganist Werckmeister became known to posterity more as a music theorist, especially with his writings Musicae mathematicae hodegus curiosus... (1687) and Musikalische Temperatur, oder... (1691), as well as the posthumously published work Musicalische Paradoxal-Discourse (1707), in which he described the well-tempered tunings named after him (Werckmeister tuning).
=590  \\$aund wie hingegen dieselbe so sehr gemissbrauchet wird. Dann, wie dieselbe von den lieben Alten mit grosser Schwürig- und Weitläufftigkeit, welche uns zum Theil noch anhanget, ist fortgesetzet worden und wie man hingegen in vielen Stücken, in heutiger Musica practica eines nähern Weges und Vortheils sich bedienen könne, &c. So wohl denen, so ihre Music zur Ehre Gottes gedencken anzuwenden, auch andern Gott- und Kirchen-Music Liebenden zum weitern Nachdencken mathematicè, historicè, und allegoricè, durch die musicalischen Proportional-Zahlen entdecket

=041  \\$afre
=059  \\$apf/hpd
=245  \\$aSix airs de différens opéras comiques arrangés pour le piano forte ou le clavecin
=260  \\$aParis$bs.n.$cs.d.
=300  \\$a13 pages
=500  \\$aoffered to Ton Koopman by the Vrienden van het Amsterdam Baroque Orchestra & Choir for his seventieth birthday, October 2014
=500  \\$aed. by Valentin Roeser?
=500  \\$aArrangements of arias from 
"Rose et Colas" Monsigny 1764 (Pauvre Colas), 
"Le Roi et le Fermier" by Monsigny 1762 (Ce n'est qu'ici , non ce n'est qu'au village), 
"Le Huron" Gretry 1767 (Si jamais je prends un époux, and Ma bonne amie est il possible),

=245  \\$aThe Musical Cyclopedia;$bBeing a collection of the most approved English, Scottish and Irish songs;
=260  \\$aLondon$bBell$c1836
=300  \\$alxxxiv-272 pages
=500  \\$aThe Songbook is preceded by a lengthy essay (84 pages) on musical theory 'The first Principles of Music' by William Grier.
=500  \\$aQuite some songs are by Robert Burns (1759–1796) generally considered the national poet of Scotland, not only for his poems but for his songs. He avidly collected traditional melodies and composed lyrics to them if these did not exist; if they did exist, he passionately fought to preserve them in their original Scots form rather than Anglicize them.

=041  \\$ager
=100  \\$aScriver, Christian$d1629-1693$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q73764$97869
=245  \\$aM. Christian Scrivers Seelen-Schatzes $bFünffter und letzter Theil$npart 1-2/2
=260  \\$aLeipzig$bLüderwald; Gerlach$c1696
=300  \\$a2 parts ([vi]-532-[26] + [vi]-230-[21] pages)$btitle page engraved , black & red ink
=500  \\$aOriginally published in 1675-1692
=500  \\$aChristian Scriver (1629-1693) was a Lutheran minister and devotional writer
=500  \\$ahe was a friend of Philipp Jakob Spener, the 'Father of Pietism'
=500  \\$aHis most important work was Seelen-Schatz ("The Soul's Treasure", 5 parts, 1675-1692; new ed., 3 vols., Berlin, 1852–53), describing the progress of the soul from misery to eternal life and combining allegory, dogmatics, and ethics. It has been translated into numerous languages.
=504  \\$aindex
=590  \\$a "Darinn von der gläubigen Seelen Verlangen nach dem Ewigen Vorbereitung zum seligen Tode frölichem Abschied aus der Weltseligen Einzug in dem Himmel und Geniessung der ewigen Seligkeit, ausführlich und erbaulich gehandelt wird"
=648  \0$a17th Century (1601-1700)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7016$920923
=650  \0$aReligion$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q9174$93062
=650  \0$aAllegory$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q18535$93718
=650  \0$aMoral education$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q25457248$93171

=590  \\$aWelches die Melodien derer so wohl alten als neuen biß hieher eingeführten Gesänge unsers Teutschlandes in sich hält auch durch eine besondere Einrichtung dergestalt verfasset ist, daß diejenige Lieder, so man nicht zu singen gewußt, nunmehro mit ihren behörigen Melodien gesungen, und mit der Orgel oder Clavier accompagnirt werden können. Ferner finden sich darinnen die Melodien derer Hundert und Funffzig Psalmen Davids, wie solche in denen Gemeinden der Reformirten Kirche gesungen werden, benebst denen Frantzösischen Liedern, so viel deren biß itzo bekannt worden Zum  Lobe Gottes und Berförderung der Andacht aufs sorgfältigste zusammen getragen, anbey durchgehends mit einem modernen General-Bass versehen, und samt einem Vorbericht in dieser bequemen Form ans Licht gestellet von Johann Balthasar König, Directore Chori Musices in Franckfurt am Mayn

=041  \\$ager
=100  \\$aSulzer, Johann Georg$d1720-1779$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q27598299$97607
=245  \\$aAllgemeine Theorie der schönen Künste$bin einzeln, nach alphabetischer Ordnung der Kunstwörter auf einander folgenden, Artikeln abgehandelt
=250  \\$a3rd rev. ed.
=260  \\$aFrankfurt$aLeipzig$bs.n.$c1798
=300  \\$a4 vols. (xxiv-819+763+829+896 pages)$bfrontispiece engraving, illustrations, folded pages, music examples
=500  \\$aCited in Koopman 1985, 107
=500  \\$aTheoretical dictionary of the three fine arts of painting, sculpture and architecture as well as of poetry and music.
=500  \\$aTitle-page engraving by Daniel Chodowiecki  (1726-1801), German-Polish painter and printmaker. Allegory of the fine arts: the picture shows a light female figure surrounded by Minerva and the Graces. Minerva sits with lance and medusa shield. At her feet are tools for carving stone, a palette, brush, compass and square, masks and cothurn, a shawm and a plectrum. Minerva looks up at the female figure standing next to her, her gaze directed into the distance as if listening to an inner voice. A bright sun shines above the standing one. Minerva points with her hand to the instruments on the floor which refer to the three fine arts of painting, sculpture and architecture as well as to poetry and music.the three graces, meanwhile, are busy endowing the standing female figure with attributes that point to various arts. In the background, a landscape opens up in the depths, in which a naked, still uncivilised human family sits in front of a kind of primitive hut while one of them chases a deer. (Veronika Mertens, Die drei Grazien, Studien zu einem Bildmotiv in der Kunst der Neuzeit, Harrassowitz Verlag, 1994)
=534  \\$aOriginally published in 1771-74
=561  \\$aEx Libris Clauswitz (manuscript)
Ex Libris BJ Gamborg 1916 (manuscript)

=041  \\$ager
=059  \\$aorg
=100  \\$aRinck, Christian Heinrich$d1770-1846$4cmp$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q559451$96535
=245  \\$aNeues Choralbuch für das Großherzogthum Hessen
=260  \\$aOffenbach am Main$bAndré$c1814
=300  \\$axviii-100-xx pages$b16x23 cm, oblong
=500  \\$aorgan accompaniment for a collection of 138 chorales
=500  \\$aRinck comes from a family of teachers. From 1786, he received organ and composition lessons from a pupil of Johann Sebastian Bach, by Johann Christian Kittel (1732-1809) in Erfurt. In 1805 he moved to Darmstadt and become cantor and organist at the city church. Later he was employed as court organist and chamber musician of Grand Duke Louis I of Hesse-Darmstadt. 
Rinck was known early on as an excellent organist and was much in demand as an expert.His organ compositions were highly appreciated and his "Praktische Orgelschule", op. 55 was a leading method in Germany until the 20th century. Rinck made an important contribution to the renewal and improvement of Protestant organ music at the beginning of the 19th century.

=245  \\$aAdvertissement of Waarschouwinge aan alle liefhebbers van den waren Christelyken Godtsdienst, aangaande den rechten toestant der vermaadre Akademie van Utrecht

=501  \\$aRedenvoering voor de comedie
Noodig verweer-schrift voor den Nederduitschen Kerken-raadt van Utrecht
Kortbondig vertoog van de onbetamelijkheit en schadelijkheit der comedien
Wederlegging van het zoogenaamde verweerschrift voor de Nederduitze Kerkenraad van Utrecht en het kortbondig vertoog van de onbetamelykheid en schadelykheid der comedien
Bekentmaking van het roekeloos bestaan van Pieter Burman, vermaart Professor in de Akademie van Utrecht
Antwoord van A. J. Brakonier, C. Boott, Ae. vande Putt, en A. Driessen, predikanten te Utrecht, op Profr. Pieter Burmans zoogenaamde wederlegginge van 't noodig verweerschrift

De gehoonde eer van God den hoogsten wetgever, en Zyn oppergebied over de koninkryken en staten van de wereld
Ad mirmillones sine missione depugnantes

=041  \\$adut
=245  \\$aBekentmaking van het roekeloos bestaan van Pieter Burman, vermaart Professor in de Akademie van Utrecht
=260  \\$as.l.$bs.n.$c1712
=300  \\$a46 pages
=500  \\$ap.41-46: "Byvoegsel, eener senstige aansprake van P.B. Oppersten Voorstander van de Komedie, Aan zyne geliefde Broederen de Atheisten, nu bekent onder de name van Spinozisten, Leenhovisten, Bekkerianen, Libertynen, enz: echte kinderen van Sofia Carnalis, en burgeren van de Beestenhemel op aarde."
=501  \\$aRedenvoering voor de comedie
Noodig verweer-schrift voor den Nederduitschen Kerken-raadt van Utrecht
Kortbondig vertoog van de onbetamelijkheit en schadelijkheit der comedien
Wederlegging van het zoogenaamde verweerschrift voor de Nederduitze Kerkenraad van Utrecht en het kortbondig vertoog van de onbetamelykheid en schadelykheid der comedien
Antwoord van A. J. Brakonier, C. Boott, Ae. vande Putt, en A. Driessen, predikanten te Utrecht, op Profr. Pieter Burmans zoogenaamde wederlegginge van 't noodig verweerschrift

=501  \\$aRedenvoering voor de comedie
Noodig verweer-schrift voor den Nederduitschen Kerken-raadt van Utrecht

=245  \\$aKortbondig vertoog van de onbetamelijkheit en schadelijkheit der comedien

=300  \\$a36 pages
=500  \\$areaction to Burman's 'Redenvoering voor de comedie'
=501  \\$aRedenvoering voor de comedie
Noodig verweer-schrift voor den Nederduitschen Kerken-raadt van Utrecht
Wederlegging van het zoogenaamde verweerschrift voor de Nederduitze Kerkenraad van Utrecht en het kortbondig vertoog van de onbetamelykheid en schadelykheid der comedien
Bekentmaking van het roekeloos bestaan van Pieter Burman, vermaart Professor in de Akademie van Utrecht
Antwoord van A. J. Brakonier, C. Boott, Ae. vande Putt, en A. Driessen, predikanten te Utrecht, op Profr. Pieter Burmans zoogenaamde wederlegginge van 't noodig verweerschrift
Tweede wederlegginge van het antwoord van de vier Utrechtze predikanten vol. 1
Tweede wederlegginge der vier Utrechtse predikanten vols. 2-3
De gehoonde eer van God den hoogsten wetgever, en Zyn oppergebied over de koninkryken en staten van de wereld
Ad mirmillones sine missione depugnantes
Advertissement of Waarschouwinge aan alle liefhebbers van den waren Christelyken Godtsdienst, aangaande den rechten toestant der vermaadre Akademie van Utrecht
=590  \\$abyzonder ook der hedendaagse, zijnde een vervolg van 't Noodig verweer-schrift voor den Nederduitschen kerken-raadt van Utrecht

=245  \\$aDer Gelehrte Narr
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aFreiburg$bFaßmann$c1729
=300  \\$a[35]-222 pages
=500  \\$alovely caricatural frontispiece
=500  \\$aDavid F. Faßmann (1685-1744) was a popular journalist, a member of the tobacco college and historiographer
=501  \\$aFaßmann's 'Die neu-entdeckten Elisäischen Felder' (1735)
=590  \\$aOder gantz natürliche Abbildung solcher Gelehrten, die da vermeynen alle Gelehrsamkeit und Wissenschafften verschlucket zu haben, auch in dem Wahn stehen, daß ihres gleichen nicht auf Erden zu finden, wannenhero sie alle andere Menschen gegen sich verachten, einen unerträglichen Stoltz und Hochmuth von sich spüren lassen; in der That aber doch selber so, wie sie in ihrer Haut stecken, Ignoranten, Pedanten, ja Ertz-Fantasten und tumme Sympel sind, die von der wahren Gelehrsamkeit, womit die Weisheit verknüpffet seyn muß, weit entfernet. Nebst einer lustigen Dedication und sonderbaren Vorrede. Dergleichen verkehrten Gelehrten zur guten Lehre, und verhoffentlich daraus fliessenden Besserung; andern aber, so sich denen Studiis widmen, und noch Anfänger sind, zur getreuen Warnung, auch sonst jederman zum Vergnügen geschrieben

Wilh. Freyh. v. Kyau, Und Der durch seine Avanturen am Königlichen Preußischen Hofe in der Welt sehr bekandt gewordene Geheime Rath und Freyherr, Jacob Paul von Gundling, daselbst einander angetroffen : Worinnen überaus merckwürdige und sinnreiche Discurse, samt der wahrhafften Lebensbeschreibung beyder angeführten Personen enthalten Durchgehends lustig und ergetzend zu lesen, doch so, daß da und dorten auch sehr ernsthaffte Reflexiones mit untermischet sind

=590  \\$ain Nederduytse sang-versen, oude en nieuwe rymen : begrypende d'oude, alle de van ouds in gebruyk zynde Psalmen, eertyds gerymt door Willem van Haagt: en de nieuwe, alle de buyten gebruyk geblevene Psalmen, namaals van hare onbekende, op bekende kerk-sangwysen gestelt en gerymt, door J. v. Duisberg. Aldus geheel op bekende Sang-wysen, benevens alle de gewone geestelyke liederen, tendienste van de christelyke gemeynten van d'onveranderde Augsburgsche Geloofs-Belydenis, in 't ligt gegeven en met eenige nieuw-geapprobeerde liederen vermeerdert. =245  \\$aSpelen van sinne, vol scoone moralisacien, uutleggingen ende bediedenissen op alle loeflijcke consten
=260  \\$aAntwerp$bSilvius$c1562
=300  \\$a[499]-[246] pages$bplate, ill., folded page
=500  \\$aat two thirds of the volume there is a new title-page, with same imprint: "Spelen van sinne waer inne alle oirboirlijcke ende eerlijcke handwercken ghepresen ende verhaelt worden"
=561  \\$aEx libris Seth Gaaikema
=590  \\$avvaer inne men claerlijck ghelijck in eenen spieghel, figuerlijck, poetelijck en̄ retorijckelijck mach aenschouwen hoe nootsakelijck ende dienstelijck die selue consten allen menschen zijn : ghespeelt met octroy der Con. Ma. binnen der stadt van Andtwerpen op dLant-Juweel by die veerthien cameren van retorijcken die hen daer ghepresenteert hebben den derden dach augusti int jaer ons Heeren M. D. LXJ. : op die questie, vvat den mensch aldermeest tot conste vervvect : tot groote onderwijsinghe van allen liefhebbers der poeterie ende retorijcke gheciert met diuersse schoone figueren.

=008  210716s1643\\\\\\\|||||\||||\00|\0\lat\d
=041  \\$alat
=100  \\$aZehentner, Paul$d1589-1648$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q55874362$97979
=245  \\$aPromontorium malæ spei: impiis periculose navigantibus propositum
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aHaupt; Widmanstadt$bGraz$c1643
=300  \\$a[xxxviii]-752-[10] pages$bgilt edges, 2 engravings
=500  \\$aJesuit warning of the consequences of licentiousness ("Promontory, thoughts of hope for the wicked goal that sailed dangerously. Whether it is a sign of rejection and note: procrastination of repentance written precautionary men's amendment is reluctance, sometimes hope to repent.")
=500  \\$aFirst and only edition of a Latin edifying text on moral and religious issues by the Jesuit Paul Zehentner (1589-1648), preacher at the Graz court of the widow of the Holy Roman Emperor Ferdinand II and teacher of grammar, the humanities and the Holy Scripture at Millestadt in Austria. A moral-theological treatment of state theory, astrology and magic, intended to highlight the dangers of licentious behaviour. 
=500  \\$aIt provides our first known reference to the tragedy of Leontius, a play Zehentner saw at the Jesuit University in Ingolstadt in 1615, and which was to serve as a prototype for the Don Juan legend (Keefe, Mozart studies, p. 140). 
=500  \\$aZehentner dedicated the book to Leonardus Helfridus, Count at Maggau, 26 October 1643, and received a privilege from the Holy Roman Emperor Ferdinand III.
=500  \\$aEngraved allegorical frontispiece and a richly designed armorial and emblematic dedication plate, both by David Tscherning.
=504  \\$aindex
=590  \\$aSive, signum & nota reprobationis: procrastinatio poenitentiae, scripta cautelae hominum, emendatione[m] vita[e] cunctantium, spe aliquando resipiscendi.
=610  \0$aJesuits$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q36380$921140

=100  \\$aLogier, Johann Bernhard$d1777-1846$4aut$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q318065$96172
=245  \\$aSystem der Musik-Wissenschaft und der praktischen Composition
=260  \\$aBerlin$bLogier$c1827
=300  \\$axii-346-[4]-13 pages$bmusical examples, frontispiece illustration
=500  \\$aIn 1822 Logier was called to Berlin to help found a music academy, and subsequently trained elementary teachers on behalf of the king until 1826. In addition, the publishing house of his brother Wilhelm published his textbooks in German.  In this method, several pupils are taught at a time, with technical instruction done together with instruction in principles of harmony. This lay the basis of group teaching in music.

=100  \\$aGoodwin, Starling$d1711-1774$4cmp$98092
=245  \\$aThe Complete Organists Pocket Companion$bContaining a choice Collection of Psalm-Tunes with their Givings-Out, and Interludes
=260  \\$aLondon$bThompson$c17xx
=300  \\$a[ii]-64 pages
=500  \\$aA blind 18th century musician based in London, Starling Goodwin wrote music both for church use and public concerts. Surviving examples of his work include voluntaries for organ or harpsichord and a number of popular light entertainment songs. One of the greatest pluralists of his profession, he was organist at four London churches simultaneously at the time of his death. He was also a witty and amusing socialiser and an accomplished violinist.
=500  \\$apublished in or after 1774 (title page mentions :... by the "late" Mr. Starling Goodwin)
=590  \\$aas used in Parish Churches

=008  210628s1745\\\\\\\||k||\||||\00|\0\mul\d
=041  \\$adut$alat
=041  \\$alat
=059  \\$av
=245  \\$aMissen en gezangen
=250  \\$a1st ed.
=260  \\$aUtrecht$bWeyde, van der$c1745
=300  \\$a[i]-48-[2] pages
=500  \\$aThe so-called 'Stukjesboek', which formed the basis of the old Catholic church song in the Netherlands: 98 songs in Latin and Dutch, plus three ordinaria in Latin. Strong Jansenist influence.
=500  \\$aMissen en Gezangen is not the only para-liturgical hymnbook that the Utrecht Church had after the schism of 1723.
Some of the material it contains had already been published in Het Paradijs, which appeared in eight editions between 1621 and 1679 in Antwerp, or in Het Prieel, Brugues 1609/l0. Also the collection of Gulielmus de Swaen, parish priest in Gouda, to which he gave the name Den Singende Swaen'[, -an allusion to his own name, which means 'swan', - contains pieces that can be found in Missen en Gezangen. Of a substantial part, however, the origin remains obscure. No doubt a large repertoire of Latin and Dutch hymns was known from the rather isolated milieu of the Utrecht church. It is even possible that the type of hymns found in Missen en Gezangen and the other collections mentioned, were cherished by the secular clergy and that their use was discouraged, more or less, by the regulars. It is at least curious that in the Old Catholic Church an abundance of hymns have survived, while they are relatively rare in the Roman Catholic Church parishes in Friesland and northern Holland.
=500  \\$aIn Missen en Gezangen we find texts by Andreas van der Schuur and Jean Baptiste Stalpaert van der Wielen , but most of the texts are from the Counter-Reformation period and are anonymous.
=500  \\$aAndreas van der Schuur (also Van der Schuer) (1656- 1719) was ordained a priest in 1680 and became parish priest in Vianen in 1692. Archbishop Van Neercassel entrusted him with the translation of the Bible  in 1732, completed by H. van Rhijn. He was the composer of several religious poems, both Latin and Dutch.


=500  \\$aJean Baptiste Stalpa(e)rt van der Wiele(n) (1579 - 1630), a lawyer in The Hague in 1598,  became a priest in 1606. In 1613 he was appointed parish priest in Delft, where he remained until his death. In 1621 he published "Hemelrijk", in 1622 "Het vrouwelick cieraed van St Agnes", religious poetry. In prose he published "Roomsche Reys" in 1624, and in 1628 a collection of hymns "'t
Gulden Jaer ons'Heeren Jesu Christi". As a posthumous work he published "Extractum Catholicum" and "Guide Jaers Feestdaghen of de Schat der gheestelijekeLofsanghen", in 1631 and 1634. He was the composer of about 2000 hymns.


=504  \\$ahttps://www.e-periodica.ch/cntmng?pid=ikz-002:1983:73::353

=651  \0$aUtrecht (Netherlands)$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q803$9141

=500  \\$aengraved frontispiece "Fame honours the Guida Armonica"  by Simon François Ravenel l'Ancien (1706-1774) after Edme Bouchardon (1698-1762). Fame hovers in the air above the sea (where a boat is floating) and a beach where there is a globe, symbols of the arts (flute and score, bust, palette and brushes, compass) and a military trophy (armour, helmet, shield, sword, arrows), probably alluding to the Prince of Wales, the musician's patron.

=245  \\$aHandel's Dead March in Saul: N° Duet [HWV 53]
=260  \\$aLondon$bChappell$c18xx
=300  \\$a5 pages$billustrated title page
=500  \\$aBeautiful title-page with lithograph depicting a parade, church interiors and the exterior of St Paul's cathedral: pages 2-3 have it that "This solemn and pathetic composition was written for the Oratorio of Saul in 1738. It was performed at the interment of George the Second, which first originated the custom of making it part of the burial ceremony."'

=500  \\$a Yearbook of the Katharineum in Lübeck, a gymnasium famous for its curriculum of the trivium (grammar, rhetoric and logic), the quadrivium (arithmetic, geometry, music, and astronomy), as well as the study of literature, poetry, drama, philosophy, history, art, and languages.
