=LDR  02418nam a22002297a 4500
=001  22740
=008  240201s2024\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=044  \\$aBE
=100  \\$aBeghin, Tom$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q93244160$1https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7919-8985$4Creator$917739
=245  \\$aLecture: Bis repetita placent: C. P. E. Bach, W. A. Mozart, and the Practice of Varied Reprises
=260  \\$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-08-03
=500  \\$aAbstract: 
In 1775 Leopold Mozart inquired with Breitkopf in Leipzig whether he might like to print an opus of keyboard sonatas by his son, Wolfgang Amadeus, “in the same manner as those of H: Philipp Carl Emanuel Bach mit veränderten Reprisen.” Pitching Wolfgang’s recently completed Sonatas K 279–284 (1774–75), Leopold may also have intended for his nineteen-year-old son to tap into a potentially lucrative amateur market. The publication did not happen, but the question is intriguing: what might such Mozart Sonatas with Varied Reprises have looked like?
            Some larger questions emerge. When performing classical keyboard sonatas, what happens when we submit ourselves to the expectation of continuous variation? How do we navigate the materiality of a printed score? What are the limits to incorporating our variants and at what point do we feel like starting over, and re-composing altogether? How do we tap into the eighteenth-century ideal of a keyboardist as composer-performer, while becoming sensitive to a musical culture that harbored a more fluent use of a musical work, tailored to the needs of a performer?
            These questions will be balanced against an exploration of rhetorical intent behind repetition and variation, Bach’s published thoughts on the matter, and own experiments of teaching and performing Mozart’s sonatas on a Stein fortepiano as the instrument that in 1777 became crucial in the professional life of a maturing improviser and composer.

=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aForte/Piano Summer Academy
Music Department, Cornell University (Ithaca, NY, US)

=591  \\$a1
=610  \0$aDeclassifying the Classics: Rhetoric, Technology, and Performance, 1750-1850$926931
=856  \\$3Universal Resource Locator$uhttps://historicalkeyboards.as.cornell.edu/fortepiano-summer-academy-2024-chamber-music-collective-piano-tech-academy-showcase
=942  \\$cNWO
=999  \\$d22740

=LDR  01995ngm a22002297a 4500
=001  22743
=008  240201s2024\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=044  \\$aBE
=100  \\$aBeghin, Tom$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q93244160$1https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7919-8985$4Creator$917739
=245  \\$aCarl Philipp Emanuel Bach (1714–1788): Six Sonatas with Varied Reprises, Wq 50
=260  \\$bEvil Penguin TV and Orpheus Instituut$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-12-16
=500  \\$aAbstract:
C. P. E. Bach’s Sonatas with Varied Reprises, published in Berlin, 1760, constituted a bold experiment. Throughout this opus of six Bach spelled out every repeat, integrating into the printed text his own composed variations. This practice of varying repeats normally belonged to the realm of the performer, so Bach was treading on unchartered territory, even inventing (in his own words) “a new genre.” Starting off as a service (“play this and you’ll sound as if you’re improvising”), the opus ends up a masterclass in variation. Tom Beghin, playing his own beloved clavichord (by Joris Potvlieghe, 2003), enacts the role of the keyboardist-composer who repeats himself, while never saying the same thing twice.

=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aTom Beghin, clavichord

Directed by Tom Beghin and Anastasios Zafeiropoulos
Camera: Bo Aerts and Xin Van Damme
Video editing: Bo Aerts, with Xin Van Damme
Sound: Steven Maes, George Georgiev, and Lowie Peeters
Sound artistic supervision: Luca Montebugnoli
Sound editing: Tom Beghin
Sound mastering: Steven Maes
Filmed at Koetshuis, Orpheus Instituut, Ghent, June 1–2, 2024
An Orpheus Instituut and Evil Penguin TV production

=245  \\$aC. P. E. Bach: Sonatas with Varied Reprises, Wq 50
=260  \\$bEvil Penguin Classic$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-10-25
=500  \\$aAbstract:
Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach’s Sonatas with Varied Reprises (published in Berlin, 1760) constituted a bold experiment. Spelling out every repeat, Bach applies to each the art of variation. Starting off as a service (“play this and you’ll sound as if you’re improvising”), the opus ends up a masterclass in variation. Tom Beghin, playing his own beloved clavichord, enacts the role of the keyboardist-composer who repeats himself, while never saying the same thing twice.

=245  \\$aAfterwork Concert No. 3, “Mit veränderten Reprisen”
=260  \\$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-02-07
=500  \\$aAbstract:
Performing on clavichord and fortepiano, Tom Beghin explores a once lively practice of varying repeats through two sets of keyboard sonatas—for a total of twelve, to be digested in groups of three: CPE Bach’s Sechs Sonaten mit veränderten Reprisen, Wq 50 (1760) and Mozart’s six “Munich” Sonatas K 279–285 (1774–75).

=100  \\$aBeghin, Tom$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q93244160$1https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7919-8985$4Creator$917739
=245  \\$aForte/Piano Summer Academy: Showcase Salon Concert
=260  \\$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-08-02
=500  \\$aAbstract:
In 1775 Leopold Mozart inquired with Breitkopf in Leipzig whether he might like to print an opus of keyboard sonatas by Wolfgang Amadeus, “in the same manner as those of H: Philipp Carl Emanuel Bach mit veränderten Reprisen.” Almost certainly, Leopold was pitching his son’s recently completed Sonatas K. 279-284 (1774-75). The publication did not happen, but the question is intriguing: what might Mozart’s Six Sonatas with Varied Reprises have looked like?
Alternately on clavichord and fortepiano, this concert features two Sonatas with Varied Reprises by C. P. E. Bach, the third and fourth of Wq 50 (published in 1760), along with K 279 and K 282 of Mozart, as the first and fourth of an opus that might have been published with written-out repeat and variation.

=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aA. D. White House, Cornell University, Ithaca (NY, US)
Program:

W. A. Mozart, Sonata in C Major, K 279
Bach, Sonata in D Minor, Wq 50/4
Mozart, Sonata in E-flat Major, K 282
On clavichord (replica of C. E. Friederici, 1765) and fortepiano (replica of Stein, 1784)

=001  22749
=008  240201s2024\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=044  \\$aBE
=100  \\$aBeghin, Tom$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q93244160$1https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7919-8985$4Creator$917739
=245  \\$aVirtual Music Experiences in the Metaverse: Digital Twin
=260  \\$aGhent$bWintercircus$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-11-27
=500  \\$aAbstract:
This interdisciplinary research project, with sound recording engineers at PXL Music (Hasselt) and video animation researchers at Howest (Kortrijk), has explored the making of digital twins.  Tom Beghin recorded a short piece by W. A. Mozart (the third movement of the Sonata in E-flat Major, K 282), using a replica of a Stein fortepiano (by Chris Maene, 2016, after an original of 1788).  Digital twins were produced both of instrument and performer (using 3D scanning and MetaHuman Creator).  Beghin then played the recorded piece again, using the same instrument and wearing an X Sense Suit, while his movements were mapped using techniques like Mocap and Optitrack (for finger tracking, body movement, and face animations).  Meanwhile, virtual acoustic renderings of two performance venues were combined with animated visual reconstructions of De Kreun (a modern concert hall in Kortrijk) and the ceremonial room of D’Hane-Steenhuyse (an 18th-century palace in Ghent).  The result is an interactive video presentation where all aspects of the animation are combined and synchronized, and where the user, wearing binaural headphones and a VR glasses, can freely walk through a chosen virtual space, randomly switching between D’Hane-Steenhuyse and De Kreun, while fluidly experiencing a “digital twin” performance.

=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aFinal schowcase event (“Digital Twin”) of Virtual Music Experiences in the Metaverse, a multi-year research project with PXL Music (Hasselt) and Digital Arts and Entertainment (Kortrijk), funded by VLAIO

=245  \\$aConcert: “La bande de Gluck: Accompanied Piano Music in Revolutionary Paris”
=260  \\$aKouter, Ghent$bClub Falligan$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-04-23
=500  \\$aAbstract:
Luca Montebugnoli (piano) and Laura Andriani (violin) explore links with Christoph Willibald Gluck’s operas in the accompanied piano music of Jean-Louis Adam, Jean-Frédéric Edelmann, and Daniel Steibelt. Playing a 1791 Pascal Taskin square piano, freshly restored by Pianos Maene (Ruiselede), they bring to life pre- and post-revolutionary repertoire from the Parisian salon, alternating original music for piano and violin with arrangements.

=041  \\$aeng
=100  1\$aPare, Arabella$1https://orcid.org/0009-0005-4025-7227$4First author$927042
=245  \\$aKarl Böhm’s 1939 Recordings of the Beethoven Piano Concertos op. 37, op. 58, and op. 73
=260  \\$aMunich$bEdition Text+Kritik$c2025
=366  \\$b2025-03-03
=506  \\$aClosed
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aAn interpretational analysis of performance practices and artistic/aesthetic choices in the context of three early recordings of the Beethoven piano concertos Op. 37, Op. 58, and Op. 73. This paper investigates the context of the recordings, the relationship between Karm Böhm and the Sächsische Staatskapelle, and the interaction of the former two acteurs with the three soloists Lubka Kolessa, Walther Gieseking, and Edwin Fischer. 
=591  \\$aEditorial review
=600  \\$1Ludwig van Beethoven
=600  \\$1Walter Gieseking
=600  \\$1Lubka Kolessa
=600  \\$1Edwin Fischer
=600  \\$1Karl Böhm
=610  \0$aFragment: Accordances - Enactments$940145
=773  \\$g407-441$tKarl Böhm Biografie, Wirken, Rezeption$z978-3-96707-584-7
=856  \\$3Universal Resource Locator$uhttps://www.etk-muenchen.de/search/Details.aspx?sort=1&q=karl+b%C3%B6hm&ISBN=9783967075847
=942  \\$cCHA
=999  \\$d22759

=245  \\$a“An Essay on the True Art of Varying: C. P. E. Bach’s Sonatas with Varied Reprises”
=260  \\$aMechelen$bEvil Penguin Classic$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-10-25
=500  \\$aAbstract:
Elucidates the historical, socio-cultural, and rhetorical context for C. P. E. Bach’s publication of Sonatas with Varied Reprises (1760), as well as the performance decisions made for a recording of Bach’s original set (CD 1), along with additional variants by Bach himself (CD 2).

=100  \\$aMontebugnoli, Luca$1https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3822-016X$4Creator$925649
=245  \\$aConcert: “La bande de Gluck: Accompanied Piano Music in Revolutionary Paris”
=260  \\$aKouter, Ghent$bClub Falligan$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-04-23
=500  \\$aAbstract:
Luca Montebugnoli (piano) and Laura Andriani (violin) explore links with Christoph Willibald Gluck’s operas in the accompanied piano music of Jean-Louis Adam, Jean-Frédéric Edelmann, and Daniel Steibelt. Playing a 1791 Pascal Taskin square piano, freshly restored by Pianos Maene (Ruiselede), they bring to life pre- and post-revolutionary repertoire from the Parisian salon, alternating original music for piano and violin with arrangements.

=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aLuca Montebugnoli, piano
Laura Andriani, violin

Program:
C. W. Gluck, Iphigénie en Aulide, Wq. 40, arranged by J.-F. Edelmann
Jean-Frédéric Edelmann, Sonata in G Minor, Op. 6 No. 1
D. Steibelt, Mélange d’airs et de chants, Op. 10
C. W. Gluck, Echo et Narcisse, Wq. 47, arranged by J.-L. Adam
J.-L. Adam, Sonata in G Minor, Op. 7 No. 1

=245  \\$aAfterwork Concert No. 5: “La bande de Gluck: Accompanied Piano Music in Revolutionary Paris”
=260  \\$a Ghent$bOrpheus Instituut$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-04-24
=500  \\$aAbstract:
Luca Montebugnoli (piano) and Laura Andriani (violin) explore links with Christoph Willibald Gluck’s operas in the accompanied piano music of Jean-Louis Adam, Jean-Frédéric Edelmann, and Daniel Steibelt. Playing a 1791 Pascal Taskin square piano, freshly restored by Pianos Maene (Ruiselede), they bring to life pre- and post-revolutionary repertoire from the Parisian salon, alternating original music for piano and violin with arrangements.

=044  \\$aBE
=100  \\$aZafeiropoulos, Anastasios$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q61768251$4Creator$926639
=245  \\$aAfterwork Concert No. 3, “Mit veränderten Reprisen”
=260  \\$aKoetshuis, Ghent$bOrpheus Instituut$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-02-07
=500  \\$aPerforming on clavichord and fortepiano, Tom Beghin explores a once lively practice of varying repeats through two sets of keyboard sonatas—for a total of twelve, to be digested in groups of three: CPE Bach’s Sechs Sonaten mit veränderten Reprisen, Wq 50 (1760) and Mozart’s six “Munich” Sonatas K 279–285 (1774–75).
=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aProgram:

 G. S. Löhlein, Sonata in C minor, 1765
=591  \\$a0
=610  \0$aDeclassifying the Classics: Rhetoric, Technology, and Performance, 1750-1850$926931
=856  \\$3Universal Resource Locator$uhttps://orpheusinstituut.be/en/news-and-events/afterwork-concerts-declassifying-the-classics
=942  \\$cNWO
=999  \\$d22782

=LDR  01958ngm a22002297a 4500
=001  22783
=008  240201s2024\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=044  \\$aBE
=100  \\$aZafeiropoulos, Anastasios$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q61768251$4Creator$926639
=245  \\$aCarl Philipp Emanuel Bach (1714–1788): Six Sonatas with Varied Reprises, Wq 50
=260  \\$aMechelen$bEvil Penguin TV$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-12-16
=500  \\$aAbstract:
C. P. E. Bach’s Sonatas with Varied Reprises, published in Berlin, 1760, constituted a bold experiment. Throughout this opus of six Bach spelled out every repeat, integrating into the printed text his own composed variations. This practice of varying repeats normally belonged to the realm of the performer, so Bach was treading on unchartered territory, even inventing (in his own words) “a new genre.” Starting off as a service (“play this and you’ll sound as if you’re improvising”), the opus ends up a masterclass in variation. Tom Beghin, playing his own beloved clavichord (by Joris Potvlieghe, 2003), enacts the role of the keyboardist-composer who repeats himself, while never saying the same thing twice.

=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aTom Beghin, clavichord

Directed by Tom Beghin and Anastasios Zafeiropoulos
Camera: Bo Aerts and Xin Van Damme
Video editing: Bo Aerts, with Xin Van Damme
Sound: Steven Maes, George Georgiev, and Lowie Peeters
Sound artistic supervision: Luca Montebugnoli
Sound editing: Tom Beghin
Sound mastering: Steven Maes
Filmed at Koetshuis, Orpheus Instituut, Ghent, June 1–2, 2024
An Orpheus Instituut and Evil Penguin TV production

=591  \\$a0
=610  \0$aDeclassifying the Classics: Rhetoric, Technology, and Performance, 1750-1850$926931
=856  \\$3Universal Resource Locator$uhttps://orpheusinstituut.be/en/with-varied-repeats/cd-c-p-e-bachs-sonaten-mit-veranderten-reprisen-wq-50
=942  \\$cNWO
=999  \\$d22783

=LDR  01601nam a22002177a 4500
=001  22785
=008  240201s2024\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=044  \\$aBE
=100  \\$aMontebugnoli, Luca$1https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3822-016X$4Creator$925649
=245  \\$aPresentation: Investigating and Reviving the Early Nineteenth-Century Practice of Piano Arrangement: The Case of Haydn’s “Die Vorstellung des Chaos” and Beethoven’s Eroica Symphony
=260  \\$aGhent$bOrpheus Instituut$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-04-25
=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aThis presentation examined the wave of piano reductions of Haydn’s Die Schöpfung published between 1800 and 1801, emphasizing the diversity among seven versions issued by musicians such as Müller, Neukomm, Clementi, and Steibelt. Focusing on the opening movement, “Die Vorstellung des Chaos,” the analysis compared the arrangers’ differing strategies and considered how their choices were shaped by the piano technologies of the time. The study highlighted how each version reinterprets the oratorio’s narrative and reflects the broader pianistic and cultural contexts of the early nineteenth century. The presentation concluded with a discussion of my arrangement of the fourth movement of Beethoven’s Eroica Symphony, conceived for a replica of the 1803 Erard piano owned by the composer.
=591  \\$a0

=100  \\$aMontebugnoli, Luca$1https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3822-016X$4Creator$925649
=245  \\$aThe Fortepiano in France, 1770–1815: Instruments, Sources, and Repertoire
=260  \\$aParis, France$b La Nouvelle Athènes - Centre du piano romantique and Centre de Musique Baroque de Versailles (CMBV)$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-03-03
=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aThis presentation traced the early development of French pianism and piano making between 1770 and 1815, with a focus on the emergence of a distinct French aesthetic. It combined the study of historical instruments—particularly those by makers such as Erard Frères—with an analysis of pedagogical sources, genres, and the work of major composers active during the period. Through this multifaceted approach, the presentation identified the stylistic features and cultural contexts that shaped French pianistic identity at the turn of the nineteenth century.

=245  \\$a Masterclasse: Le répertoire français pour piano seul ou accompagné du début du XIXe siècle
=246  \1$aMasterclass: Early-Nineteenth French Repertoire for Piano Solo or with Accompaniment
=260  \\$aParis; Versailles$bLa Nouvelle Athènes - Centre du piano romantique and Centre de Musique Baroque de Versailles (CMBV)$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-03-03
=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aOrganized by La Nouvelle Athènes – Centre du piano romantique and the Centre de Musique Baroque de Versailles, this masterclass focused on early 19th-century French repertoire for piano, both solo and with accompaniment. Held on two historic square pianos by Erard Frères (1806 and 1815), it brought together 15 selected participants—pianists, cellists, and flutists—at the Bachelor and Master levels. The sessions were introduced by a presentation on the early history of French pianism and the development of French pianos.

=041  \\$apor
=100  \\$aDantas, Paulo$1https://orcid.org/0009-0008-3627-5045$4First Author$926637
=245  \\$aEstar no campo: Processo, Narratividade e Descoberta nos Trabalhos de Gravação de Campo de Thelmo Cristovam e Alexandre Fenerich
=246  \1$aBeing in the Field: Process, Narrativity, and Discovery in the Field-Recording Work of Thelmo Cristovam and Alexandre Fenerich
=260  \\$aSão Paulo, Brazil$bEDUSP$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-01-01
=506  \\$aClosed
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aThe primary goal with the elaboration of the present text consists of discussing aspects of the process and creative approach of Brazilian artists Thelmo Cristovam and Alexandre Fenerich, with the aim of better understanding their artistic work involving the use of field recordings. Departing from a free reflection regarding the idea of presence in field recordings, developed around texts by Mark Peter Wright, Salomé Voegelin, Tullis Rennie and Isobel Anderson, there follows an analysis and elaborations on excerpts of original interviews and conversations with Cristovam and Fenerich, taking into account their particular narratives regarding the process of creation of such works as Duas Estórias Domésticas Colapsadas and Coleção Peripatética de Sons. This approach reveals uses of field recordings particular to these authors: Cristovam is very much aware of his presence in his recordings, even in those that are characterised by the absence of any sound of an anthropic origin. And Fenerich seems to have found a method in the wandering: there are not, necessarily, projects that are already conceived and that determine a systematic in his outings with the aim of recording. These projects could be discovered during or even after the act of recording.
=591  \\$a1
=610  \0$aMusic, Thought and Technology$926934
=773  \\$g285-303$tAlto e Bom Som: Uma História da Arte Sonora Brasileira$z9786557851692
=856  \\$3Universal Resource Locator$uwww.edusp.com.br/livros/alto-e-bom-som/
=942  \\$cCHA
=999  \\$d22789

=LDR  02113nam a22002297a 4500
=001  22790
=008  240201s2024\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=044  \\$aGB
=100  \\$aDantas, Paulo$1https://orcid.org/0009-0008-3627-5045$4Creator$926637
=111  \\$aIn the Field 2$cCRISAP$gConference
=245  \\$aSound, Routine (Meaning…): A Report
=260  \\$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-07-04
=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aIn this presentation I will reflect on experiences that prompted me to reassess some aspects of my field recording activities. Those experiences are related to the recording sessions for Cidade Arquipélago (2015), an album predominantly featuring binaural field recordings produced in Japan, conducted between 2014-15. My subsequent 2023 research in Tokyo was motivated by the realisation that many of the album's recordings presented sonic situations commonly explored by other sound artists, potentially contributing to a stereotypical portrayal of ‘Japanese (sonic) culture’. Dissatisfied, I resolved to revisit the original recording sites, focusing not on a perceived ‘Japanesenes’ of events, but on personal memories associated with the 2014-15 recordings. The 2023 recording sessions were marked by disappointment, overshadowed by the memory of the original recordings. Consequently, I shifted focus towards exploring presence, routines, and the repetitive nature of everyday life. This led my research to gradually delve into 'sound routines' found in Tokyo, providing a means to immerse in the city's rhythms through auditory experiences. A handful of sound works emerged, documenting routine phenomena by overlaying multiple recordings of the same recurring situations, while moving away from a singular focus on 'culturally symbolic' sounds. Additionally, certain sound events served as scores for electronic instruments developed during the creative process.
=591  \\$a1
=610  \0$aMusic, Thought and Technology$926934
=856  \\$3Universal Resource Locator$uvimeo.com/showcase/11312811/video/998161012
=942  \\$cNWO
=999  \\$d22790

=LDR  01321nam a22002177a 4500
=001  22791
=008  240201s2024\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=044  \\$aBE
=100  \\$aDantas, Paulo$1https://orcid.org/0009-0008-3627-5045$4Creator$926637
=245  \\$aThresh + Hold
=260  \\$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-07-19
=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aThresh + Hold is a multimodal report on the generative distance between experiences of loss as they relate to sound: losses of quality, memory, presence, time, labor, resources, intimacy, and voice. It works by juxtaposing and overlaying different kinds of loss across media formats: cyanotypes of fieldwork photos that make visible the loss of light as it imprints on the photographic medium; interlocking collages of absent sounds punctuating time spent and time lost in the field; and fragments of conversations that evoke thresholds of (mis)understanding, (mis)hearing, and (mis)communicating. By bringing together our materials, we commit to trust through tinkering and to tinkering with trust. The project received funding from the Dutch Research Council (NWO).
=591  \\$a1
=610  \0$aMusic, Thought and Technology$926934
=856  \\$3Universal Resource Locator$ufieldworks.easaonline.org/thresh-hold/

=LDR  01505nam a22002177a 4500

=008  240201s2024\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$apor
=044  \\$aBR
=100  \\$aDantas, Paulo$1https://orcid.org/0009-0008-3627-5045$4Creator$926637
=245  \\$aTokyo shitamachi: Tatekawa
=260  \\$c2025
=366  \\$b2025-01-10
=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aA simple composition using underwater stereo recordings from the Tatekawa, a river flowing into Tokyo’s Sumida River. Originally created for Mieko Matsumoto’s video in the Breathing Particles exhibition at TOKAS Hongo Gallery, Tokyo (July–August 2024). Above the river lies the Shuto Expressway, an elevated highway built for “practicality,” accelerating the river’s original transportation functions. From within the Tatekawa, the expressway’s intense activity and maintenance work are audible. On quieter days, with the use of filters, some species adapting to these changes can still be heard. These recordings layer different times and speeds in the urban “now”: the natural rivers, now channeled, and their modern counterparts—the expressways immortalized by Tarkovsky and Oshii. Distant sine wave allusions to Hana, a Western-style song by Rentaro Taki, emerge, as if engulfing the Tatekawa’s sounds.

=041  \\$aeng
=044  \\$aBE
=100  \\$aMontebugnoli, Luca$1https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3822-016X$4Creator$925649
=245  \\$aC. P. E. Bach: Sonatas with Varied Reprises, Wq 50
=260  \\$aMechelen$bEvil Penguin Classic$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-10-25
=500  \\$aAbstract:
Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach’s Sonatas with Varied Reprises (published in Berlin, 1760) constituted a bold experiment. Spelling out every repeat, Bach applies to each the art of variation. Starting off as a service (“play this and you’ll sound as if you’re improvising”), the opus ends up a masterclass in variation. Tom Beghin, playing his own beloved clavichord, enacts the role of the keyboardist-composer who repeats himself, while never saying the same thing twice.

Artistic supervision: Luca Montebugnoli
Clavichord preparation and tuning: Joris Potvlieghe
Sound editing: Tom Beghin
Sound mixing and mastering: Steven Maes
Research assistance: Anastasios Zafeiropoulos

=520  \\$aArranging Orchestral Music on an Early Nineteenth-century French Piano 
=591  \\$a0
=610  \0$aDeclassifying the Classics: Rhetoric, Technology, and Performance, 1750-1850$926931
=856  \\$3Universal Resource Locator$uhttps://orpheusinstituut.be/
=942  \\$cNWO
=999  \\$d22798

=LDR  03490nam a22002297a 4500
=001  22799
=008  240201s2024\\\\||||||||\||||\00|\0\eng\d
=041  \\$aeng
=044  \\$aIT
=100  \\$aZafeiropoulos, Anastasios$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q61768251$4Creator$926639
=245  \\$aColouring Emotions: Accompanied Keyboard Sonatas on the Fortepiano and Flute
=260  \\$aMatera, Italy$bDuni Festival$c2024
=366  \\$b2024-10-18
=500  \\$aIn accompanied sonatas, melody instruments like the flute play an optional, often improvised, lines to pre-existing keyboard pieces. This was a short-lived genre at the end of the 18th century, but an extremely popular past time among amateurs who articulated their friendships and family bonds through chamber music. In general, music was seen as the appropriate medium to express affects, or emotions, and the essence of instrumental music was closely tied to the imitation of nature and these emotional states.

The relationship to musical works was different from our time, as pieces were not yet seen as untouchable masterpieces but more like starting points for performance. As long as the music maintained its core invention, and was treated with good taste, musicians and music lovers saw no issue in altering and recycling materials. In our research concert tonight, we ask how much can be recomposed and rearranged while still sustaining the original musical ideas of the pieces performed.

The program focuses on repertoire from German regions, but influences travelled in central Europe, and the pieces could be more easily understood under the umbrella of the galant style. Johann Schobert was a German, who resettled in Paris and explored the idiom of accompanied sonatas. Bach’s sons Carl Philipp Emanuel and Wilhelm Friedemann made their livelihood in Germany following the empfindsamer Stil, or the ‘sensibility style’ which focused on intimate inflections of affects and was greatly influenced by English literature. Their little brother Johann Christian studied and worked in Italy and became subsequently a celebrated composer in England. Muzio Clementi was a Roman who resettled in London and is known nowadays as an early proponent of the piano.

The Fortepiano was a novelty of the late 18th century and hailed for its capacity to ‘sing’, to sustain a melody, and to express a broad range of dynamics and colours. It was the subject of experimentation and innovation – as much as the music written for it, in the quest to illustrate emotional experience.
=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aProgramm:

Johann Schobert (ca. 1720–1767): Accompanied keyboard sonata Eb Op. 7 No. 1

Allegro moderato – Minuetto – Allegro assai (arr. Vera Plosila & Anastasios Zafeiropoulos)


Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach (1714–1788): Rondo C Minor Wq.59 (für Kenner und Liebhaber)


Johann Christian Bach (1735–1782): Accompanied keyboard sonata A major Op. 17 No. 4

Allegretto – Pastorale. Non tanto allegro


C.P.E. Bach: Flute Sonata A Minor H. 562

Poco adagio – Allegro – Allegro


Muzio Clementi (1752–1832): Accompanied keyboard sonata F major Op. 2 No. 5

Allegro moltissimo – Allegretto


Vera Plosila, traverso

Anastasios Zafeiropoulos, fortepiano

=245  \\$aMusica ex Machina$bMachines thinking musically$cCo-curator
=260  \\$aLausanne, CH$bEPFL$c2024-5

=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$a0
=520  \\$aFrom Medieval theory to modern AI, Musica ex Machina: Machines Thinking Musically explores the history of computational and algorithmic thought in music, showcasing how technological advances and human creativity have continuously expanded the boundaries of musical expression. Through historical objects, musical artworks, and immersive installations, the exhibition presents the works of past and present visionaries while looking ahead to the future of music.

=100  \\$aCornia, Nicholas$d1989-$1https://orcid.org/0000-0003-1114-6710$4Creator$939261
=111  \\$aDialogues Artistic Research Enhancing$cRome, Italy$d14/05/2025$gConference
=245  \\$aA Praise of Falsehood: the Whirlpool of Imaginary Sounds
=260  \\$aVia dei Greci, 18 – 00187 – Roma$bConservatorio Statale di Musica di Roma “Santa Cecilia”$c2025
=366  \\$b2025-05-14
=506  \\$aopen
=509  \\$aFRIS
=520  \\$aDespite recent cultural changes, the Early Music movement remains mostly a bastion of "truth" and "authenticity" in modern times' turbulent sea of doubt. Conversely, the whirlpool of artifice project wishes to legitimize a place for falsification, fiction and imagination in the realm of historically informed practice. The hermetic title A Whirlpool of Imaginary Sounds embeds in itself the main premises of the project. First, it alludes to Italian philosopher Giulio Camillo (1480-1544), who proposed a device called artificiosa routa, a generative model ante litteram to systematize the creative process of poets and orators. Analogously with Camillo and many transgressive thinkers of the 16th and early 17th century, the project wishes to investigate the plurality of worlds hidden behind the (re)combinations of a musical knowledge system. Secondly, it is an homage to writers of fiction and thinkers like Jorge Luis Borges and Umberto Eco. Mythical creatures as well as utopian lands share a similar ascendant on our minds: through placing themselves outside reality they become powerful emblems revealing the inner meaning of things. Inspired by proto-scientific thought, poetry, devices of wonder and games from the 16th and early 17th centuries the Whirlpool of Imaginary Sounds aims to reconsider our past through polyphonic music that never was. In this project, I aspire to discover the liminal space between corpus-based musicking, forgery and period composition by reshaping the role of knowledge, either actual or imaginary, and its systematization.

=245  \\$aSuistainable Web Design
=260  \\$aUnited Kingdom$bWholegrain Books$c2021
=300  \\$a127 pages :$billustrations (color) ;$c13,97 cm.
=520  \\$aThe internet may be digital, but it carries a very physical cost. From image files to colors to coding languages to servers, the choices we make in our web work can eat up electricity and spit out carbon-and as the internet grows, so does the cost to the environment.

But there's hope: small, thoughtful changes in design and development can reduce the damage, while also making the web more resilient in the face of a changing climate. In Sustainable Web Design, Tom Greenwood offers a practical path to faster, more carbon-efficient websites that are not only better for the planet, but better for our users.

=100  \\$aCollingwood, Robin George$d1889-1943$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q317075$q(Robin George),$4aut$941410
=245  14$aThe Principles of Art
=250  \\$aPrint on demand of the 1958 edition
=260  \\$aNew York$bOxford University Press,$c1958
=300  \\$aXi, 347 pages ;$c21 cm.
=490  0\$aA Galaxy book ;$v11
=490  0\$aOxford paperbacks
=504  \\$aIncludes bibliographical references and index.
=505  0\$aIntroduction -- Book I : Art and not art -- Art and craft -- Art and representation -- Art as magic -- Art as amusement -- Art proper : (1) as expression -- Art proper : (2) as imagination -- Book II : The theory of imagination -- Thinking and feeling -- Sensation and imagination -- Imagination and consciousness -- Language -- Book III : The theory of art -- Art as language -- Art and truth -- Artist and the community -- Conclusion.
=520  \\$aThis treatise on aesthetics begins by showing that the word 'art' is used as a name not only for 'art proper' but also for certain things which are 'art falsely so called'. These are craft or skill, magic and amusement, each of which, by confusion with art proper, generates a false aesthetic theory. In the course of attacking these theories the author criticizes various psychological theories of art, offers a new theory of magic, and reinterprets Plato's so-called 'attack on art', showing that it has been entirely misunderstood. Finally, he draws important inferences concerning the position of art in human society.

=041  \\$aeng
=100  \\$aLantz, Frank$d1963-$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q16195165$4aut$941414
=245  \\$aThe Beauty of Games
=250  \\$aPaperback edition, 2025
=260  \\$aCambridge, Massachusetts$bMIT Press$c2023
=300  \\$a174 pages :$c13,33 cm.
=490  \\$aPlayful Thinking
=520  \\$aAre games art? This question is a dominant mode of thinking about games and play in the twenty-first century, but it is fundamentally the wrong question. Instead, Frank Lantz proposes in his provocative new book, The Beauty of Games, that we think about games and how they create meaning through the lens of the aesthetic. We should think of games, he writes, the same way we think of literature, theater, or music—as a form that ranges from deep and profound to easy and disposable, and everything in between. Games are the aesthetic form of interactive systems, a set of possibilities connected by rules of cause and effect.

In this book, Lantz analyzes games from chess to poker to tennis to understand how games create beauty and evoke a deeper meaning. He suggests that we think of games not only as hyper-modern objects but also as forms within the ancient context of artistic production, encompassing all of the nebulous and ephemeral qualities of the aesthetic experience.

=041  0\$aeng
=100  \\$aBrădăţan, Costică$d1971-$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q55106163$4aut$941428
=245  10$aIn Praise of Failure$bFour Lessons in Humility
=260  \\$aCambridge, Massachusetts$bHarvard University Press$c2023
=264  \1$aCambridge, Mass. ; London, England$bHarvard University Press$c2023
=300  \\$a273 pages$c14 cm.
=520  \\$aOur obsession with success is hard to overlook. Everywhere we compete, rank, and measure. Yet this relentless drive to be the best blinds us to something vitally important: the need to be humble in the face of life’s challenges. Costica Bradatan mounts his case for failure through the stories of four historical figures who led lives of impact and meaning—and assiduously courted failure. Their struggles show that engaging with our limitations can be not just therapeutic but transformative.

In Praise of Failure explores several arenas of failure, from the social and political to the spiritual and biological. It begins by examining the defiant choices of the French mystic Simone Weil, who, in sympathy with exploited workers, took up factory jobs that her frail body could not sustain. From there we turn to Mahatma Gandhi, whose punishing quest for purity drove him to ever more extreme acts of self-abnegation. Next we meet the self-styled loser E. M. Cioran, who deliberately turned his back on social acceptability, and Yukio Mishima, who reveled in a distinctly Japanese preoccupation with the noble failure, before looking to Seneca to tease out the ingredients of a good life.

Gleefully breaching the boundaries between argument and storytelling, scholarship and spiritual quest, Bradatan concludes that while success can make us shallow, our failures can lead us to humbler, more attentive, and better lived lives. We can do without success, but we are much poorer without the gifts of failure.

=041  0\$aeng$heng
=100  \\$aSuits, Bernard$d1925-2007$1http://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q28123940$4aut$941429
=245  10$aReturn of the Grasshopper$bGames, Leisure and the Good Life in the Third Millennium$cBernard Suits ; edited by Christopher C. Yorke and Francisco Javier López Frías
=260  \\$aLondon ; New York$bRoutledge, Taylor & Francis Group$c2023
=264  \1$aLondon ; New York$bRoutledge, Taylor & Francis Group$c2023
=300  \\$axxxvi, 147 pages$bIllustrations$c24 cm
=337  \\$bn$2rdamedia
=338  \\$bnc$2rdacarrier
=490  0\$aEthics and sport
=520  3\$aIn this sequel to Bernard Suits' timeless classic philosophical work The Grasshopper: Games, Life and Utopia, published in its full and unabridged form for the first time, Suits continues to explore some of our most fundamental philosophical questions, including the value of sport and games, and their relationship to the good life. In Return of the Grasshopper, Suits puts his theoretical cards on the table, exploring the in-depth implications of his definition of utopia, assessing the merits of a gamified philosophy, and explaining how games can provide an existential balm against the fear of death. Perhaps most importantly, for the first time in print, Suits reveals his underlying worldview: that humanity is forever fated to endure a cyclical existence of privation brought on by material scarcity and boredom resulting from material plenitude. An essential companion to The Grasshopper, this edition includes commentary chapters that put Suits' life and work into context, helping the reader to understand why Suits has had such a profound influence on contemporary philosophy and how his ideas still provide powerful insight into the human condition. This book is important reading for anybody with an interest in the philosophy of sport, leisure and play, political philosophy, ethics, existentialism or utopian studies
